news.title: Bill & Hillary Clinton agree to testify in House Epstein investigation ahead of contempt vote
news.text:
APFILE - Former President Bill Clinton, left, and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton listen as Vice President Kamala Harris delivers a eulogy for U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, Aug. 1, 2024, in Houston. 

Former President Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton, the 2016 Democratic ‚Å†presidential nominee, will testify in a congressional investigation into the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, a staffer said on Monday. The decision could ‚Äåhead off ‚Äåa planned vote in the Republican-led House of Representatives to hold the ‚Äåtwo prominent Democrats in contempt, which could lead to criminal charges.Budget 2026 Highlights: Here's the fine print The House Oversight Committee recommended last week that they be held in contempt for refusing to testify about their relationship with Epstein. The Clintons had offered to cooperate with the panel but had refused to appear in ‚Äåperson, saying ‚Äçthe investigation was a partisan exercise aimed ‚Äçat protecting Republican President Donald Trump. "They told you under ‚Äåoath what they know, but you don't care. But the former President and former Secretary of State will be there. They look forward to setting a precedent that applies to everyone," the Clintons' deputy chief of staff, Angel Urena, said in a post on ‚Äçsocial media. House Speaker Mike Johnson welcomed the news but did not say whether the chamber ‚Äçwould drop ‚Å†its planned ‚Å†contempt vote.Live Events "That's a good development," he said. "We expect everyone to comply with Congress's subpoenas." Bill Clinton flew on Epstein's plane several times in the early 2000s after leaving office. He has expressed regret about the relationship and said he knew nothing about Epstein's criminal activity.Add as a Reliable and Trusted News Source Add Now!
 (You can now subscribe to our Economic Times WhatsApp channel)

news.summary: Former President Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton will testify in a congressional probe concerning sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. This decision could prevent a contempt vote in the House of Representatives. The Clintons had previously refused in-person testimony, calling the investigation partisan. House Speaker Mike Johnson welcomed the development, expecting compliance with subpoenas.
news.author: Martin Shwenk Leade

news.title: Winning in Trump‚Äôs backyard and raking in money: Democrats begin 2026 with warning to Republicans
news.text:
A shock election victory for Democrats in deep-red Texas on Saturday is giving the opposition party a jolt of momentum to begin 2026 ‚Äî a year that will decide the fate of Donald Trump‚Äôs twin congressional majorities, and possibly his presidency.

Democrats elsewhere are seeing other signs, too, that the various dynamics that kept voters at home or willing to consider voting for Trump in 2024 are shifting. Despite being shy of the majority, members in both chambers are brimming with optimism and are beginning to talk openly about the possibility of pulling off a clean sweep of the GOP in November.

Saturday‚Äôs runoff election in the Fort Worth area put a northern Texas district that voted for Donald Trump by 17 points in 2024 into the hands (briefly) of a Democrat, Taylor Rehmet, who supports statewide rent stabilization, vows to halt the sale of public lands, and end charter school voucher programs. It‚Äôs a potential sign not only of the appeal of a message akin to Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs in what is thought of as a much more conservative area, but also the rejuvenation of the Democratic brand in the wake of Kamala Harris and Joe Biden‚Äôs campaign and administration.

Rehmet, who credited ‚Äúeveryday working people‚Äù in his victory speech, took money from the DNC during his election bid and was still outspent by his conservative opponent. His campaign, the Texas Tribune reported, began in part after Rehmet was introduced to a state representative who later became one of his top Latino backers at a fundraiser for the Harris campaign.

The lesson here is not that Texas has suddenly jolted blue, or that Sen. John Cornyn‚Äôs seat will change hands next year. The Texas Senate race remains favorable ground for Republicans, not least given that an ugly dispute between top Democrats vying for the seat emerged on Monday, endangering party unity and risking hurt feelings among the eventual loser‚Äôs camp. But evidence is growing to support the idea that Democrats have recaptured the enthusiasm and anger against the status quo one year into Trump‚Äôs second term, following a series of victories for the party in hotly contested statewide races.

That enthusiasm can be measured in more than just polling. It can also be measured in dollars, where Republicans are seeing their foes raise alarming sums in key races and putting their candidates at an early advantage. That reality is evident in Ohio, where Sherrod Brown is running laps around incumbent Republican Sen. Jon Husted in fundraising totals as he seeks his old job; Brown was a victim of the GOP-led wipeout in 2024. Sen. Jon Ossoff has a staggering fundraising lead of roughly $9m over any of his Republican competitors, according to Roll Call. 

And in Maine, both of Susan Collins‚Äôs would-be challengers outraised her in the last quarter of 2024, though the longtime incumbent retains a cash-on-hand advantage. The real success story in the race is Graham Platner, who is outraising both the sitting senator and sitting governor, Janet Mills, as he seeks the Democratic nomination. In Alaska, former Rep. Mary Peltola said she outraised incumbent GOP Sen. Dan Sullivan‚Äôs Q4 fundraising total in a single 24-hour period after launching her bid for Senate.

In short: Democrats are in the money. And the party‚Äôs leadership is even recovering from some of the malaise it suffered under through 2025, when leaders like Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries were faulted by some members for insufficient resistance to the Trump administration and Elon Musk‚Äôs DOGE initiative.

Jeffries was positively glowing on Monday as he spoke to reporters about the five congressional seats changed by Texas Republicans in a controversial mid-decade redistricting project aimed at giving the GOP more seats in the House: "The Republicans done effed up in Texas and they know it.‚Äù He added that he saw a path for Democrats to win all five of the newly-drawn seats.

He added that Rehmet‚Äôs victory was ‚Äúa shellacking for Republicans in Texas‚Äù over the weekend.

Democrats are clearly entering the 2026 primary season with optimism and the wind at the party‚Äôs back. In Washington, Trump‚Äôs mass deportation chaos is eroding support for Republicans on one of their strongest issues, while the party offers little in the way of a unified response on the issue of affordability.

And last week, a Florida Republican congressman announced his impending retirement. It‚Äôs a reminder that, as troubling as the map looks for Republicans now, it could look a whole lot worse if more key GOP incumbents tire of abuse from the White House and the president.

‚ÄúWe have a clear and strong path to winning back the Senate. A year ago, no one thought that,‚Äù the Democratic senate leader told Politico last month in an interview. Since January of 2025, a GOP incumbent in North Carolina, Thom Tillis, had a public break-up with Trump over the president‚Äôs legislative agenda and announced his plans to retire. Democrats are now favored to win his seat.

He added: ‚ÄúOur north star is winning the Senate. That‚Äôs what motivates what we do in each thing.‚Äù
news.summary: Another win for Democrats in Trump territory comes as the party is building a number of powerful campaign war chests, writes John Bowden
news.author: John Bowden

news.title: 'Get Ready': Trump to Sue Trevor Noah Over False 'Epstein Island' Claim
news.text:
üö® NEW: Trevor Noah makes a defamatory joke about Trump going to Epstein‚Äôs Island: ‚ÄúWhat are you to do about it?‚ÄùPresident Trump responds almost immediately saying he‚Äôs going to sue to sh!t out of him: ‚ÄúGet ready Noah, I‚Äôm going to have some fun with you!‚Äùüî•üçøü§£ü§£ pic.twitter.com/djE6uyzAf9‚Äî Chief Nerd (@TheChiefNerd) February 2, 2026

NOAH: That is a Grammy that every artist wants, almost as much as Trump wants Greenland. Which makes sense, I mean, because Epstein's island is gone. He needs a new one to hang out with Bill Clinton, so. Oh, I told you it's my last year. What are you going to do about it?

Ahem. Trump had never been to Epstein's Island, although Clinton has been rumored to have been there. In fact, it's not clear whether Epstein had the facilities for that kind of entertainment before his big construction push in 2007, well after Trump had stopped engaging with him in 2004. No evidence has emerged ‚Äì either in records or in testimony ‚Äì that Trump ever set foot on Little St. James Island while Epstein owned it. Not only has no evidence emerged for that speculation, but Trump has also repeatedly and publicly denied it whenever it came up. 

So for the answer to Noah's question, Trump supplied the obvious answer on Truth Social:

The Grammy Awards are the WORST, virtually unwatchable! CBS is lucky not to have this garbage litter their airwaves any longer. The host, Trevor Noah, whoever he may be, is almost as bad as Jimmy Kimmel at the Low Ratings Academy Awards. Noah said, INCORRECTLY about me, that Donald Trump and Bill Clinton spent time on Epstein Island. WRONG!!! I can‚Äôt speak for Bill, but I have never been to Epstein Island, nor anywhere close, and until tonight‚Äôs false and defamatory statement, have never been accused of being there, not even by the Fake News Media. Noah, a total loser, better get his facts straight, and get them straight fast. It looks like I‚Äôll be sending my lawyers to sue this poor, pathetic, talentless, dope of an M.C., and suing him for plenty$. Ask Little George Slopadopolus, and others, how that all worked out. Also ask CBS! Get ready Noah, I‚Äôm going to have some fun with you! President DJT

One has to wonder whether Noah will be the only respondent in a potential Trump lawsuit. The Recording Academy of America hired Noah to host the awards, and CBS broadcast them. They could share some liability for Noah's allegedly defamatory remarks if Trump wants to push it, and he's been wanting to "push it" ever since Democrats launched their warfare strategy to derail a return to the White House. CBS and Paramount have already paid Trump an estimated $16 million to settle an election-interference lawsuit over their cooked 60 Minutes interview with Kamala Harris, and ABC/Disney paid Trump another eight-figure settlement of about the same range for George Stephanopoulos' false claim that Trump had been convicted of rape. 

These situations are not entirely analogous, however. Both CBS and ABC had to defend news reports, while Noah's remark was intended as comedy and entertainment. That doesn't create a full immunity from defamation, but it does change the legal framework for it. Jerry Falwell learned that the hard way in attempting to sue Hustler and Larry Flynt over a satirical Campari ad that depicted him as a drunkard who had sex with his mother in an outhouse. 

However, this too has an important caveat. In its unanimous ruling in Hustler Magazine v Falwell in 1988, the Supreme Court noted that the satire was broad enough to ensure that it did not lend itself to a serious factual claim. The final paragraph makes that distinction clear as to the adjudication of both defamation and of intentional emotional distress, bold emphases mine:

Here it is clear that respondent Falwell is a "public figure" for purposes of First Amendment law. [Footnote 5] The jury found against respondent on his libel claim when it decided that the Hustler ad parody could not "reasonably be understood as describing actual facts about [respondent] or actual events in which [he] participated." App. to Pet. for Cert. C1. The Court of Appeals interpreted the jury's finding to be that the ad parody "was not reasonably believable," 797 F.2d at 1278, and, in accordance with our custom, we accept this finding. Respondent is thus relegated to his claim for damages awarded by the jury for the intentional infliction of emotional distress by "outrageous" conduct. But, for reasons heretofore stated, this claim cannot, consistently with the First Amendment, form a basis for the award of damages when the conduct in question is the publication of a caricature such as the ad parody involved here. The judgment of the Court of Appeals is accordinglyReversed.

Justice Byron White also hit this point in his concurrence:

As I see it, the decision in New York Times Co. v. Sullivan, 376 U. S. 254 (1964), has little to do with this case, for here the jury found that the ad contained no assertion of fact.

This differentiates Noah's 'joke' from the Hustler Campari ad. No one really could believe that Falwell had sex with his mother in an outhouse, and so this crude joke didn't rise to the level of a factual claim that could be found false and defamatory. Noah, on the other hand, clearly made a joke based on a factual assertion that also intended to defame Trump (and Clinton, for that matter, assuming it's false with him as well). That negates the satire shield of Hustler Magazine v Falwell, because Noah's joke was not only not wrapped in recognizable and exaggerated satire, the claim was made for an audience who would find it "reasonably believable." The point of Noah's remark would be to make that claim even more reasonably believable. 

Will that allow Trump to win a defamation suit against Noah et al? He'd still have to deal with the Sullivan doctrine, which also came up in the Falwell case. The Supreme Court's decision that no defamation took place negated any application of Sullivan, but since that doesn't apply here, it will become relevant in any action Trump takes. That was also true of Trump's lawsuit against ABC, though, and ABC/Disney tossed in the towel, perhaps in part to keep the case from potentially limiting or overturning Sullivan. However, given all of the debate over the Epstein files and Trump's connections to it, it would be tough for Noah to argue that he didn't deliberately lie or act with reckless disregard for the truth when claiming that Trump went to Epstein's island. And he would have to spend a lot of money on lawyers to fight on that basis. 

Get ready for a climbdown, in other words. I'd be surprised if it takes more than today before Noah starts backpedaling.
news.author: Ed Morrissey

news.title: Popular left-wing podcast hosts push conspiracy theory that Trump staged assassination attempt on himself
news.text: Co-hosts of the "I‚Äôve Had It" podcast on Saturday agreed in their belief that the assassination attempt on President Donald Trump‚Äôs life in Butler, Pennsylvania, was staged. Thomas Crooks opened fire at a Trump rally last year, firing eight shots, killing a man, critically wounding two others and grazing the president‚Äôs ear, according to authorities. Crooks, 20, killed a 50-year-old father of two named Corey Comperatore and sent David Dutch, 57, and James Copenhaver, 74, to the hospital with gunshot wounds. It was one of the most dramatic moments of the 2024 Trump campaign, with Trump ducking for cover with blood visible on the side of his face, as he got back up and yelled "Fight! Fight! Fight!," with a defiant fist in the air. Jennifer Welch, who famously laughed as she saw a left-wing activist take joy in TPUSA founder Charlie Kirk‚Äôs death, spoke about the Butler, PA assassination attempt with co-host Angie "Pumps" Sullivan. Welch argued that the goodwill Trump earned from that moment has not only worn itself out, but that the whole affair was likely staged. FAR-LEFT PODCAST HOST JENNIFER WELCH CLAIMS CHARLIE KIRK 'JUSTIFIED' HIS OWN DEATH "Obviously, a lot of people are late to the party on this. A lot of people during the last presidential campaign got intoxicated by Trump's campaign. They got intoxicated by the ‚ÄòFight! Fight! Fight!‚Äô photo, which I'm now going to go on the permanent record. I think he totally staged the assassination," Welch said. "I do too," Pumps replied. "I've watched it. I think he staged it. They lowered the flag. They let the press go in. I think he staged the whole thing," Welch continued. "That's just my opinion. Maybe I'm going BlueAnon. I don't care. F--- it. We're in the middle of Trump's 2.0." BlueAnon is a catchphrase that parodies the QAnon genre of conspiracy theories, and is used to describe liberals embracing similarly outlandish conspiracy theories about Republicans. She went on to criticize podcast host and comedian Andrew Schulz as one of the many male-oriented podcasters who have only recently begun to criticize Trump. WHITE HOUSE RESPONDS TO LIBERAL PODCAST HOST CALLING STEPHEN MILLER A 'NAZI JEW' "But a lot of people like Andrew Schulz fell for all that crap, and Donald Trump is a lot of these guys‚Äô idealized form of masculinity, and they submit to him, they‚Äôre submissive to this man. They don‚Äôt stand on anything on their own," Welch said. The host of the "I‚Äôve Had It" podcast proceeded to play multiple clips of Schulz complaining that only a small number of the deportations were violent/sexual offenders, and that the Trump administration had failed to release the Epstein list. "If you bring up another f------ pedophile about deporting, and you‚Äôre not releasing the Epstein list, just shut the f--- up all of you," he said. "I don‚Äôt want to hear anything else about ‚ÄòOh we gotta deport the pedophiles!‚Äô They‚Äôre right here! There are a list of them and you‚Äôre not exposing it." A White House spokesperson said the Welch and Pumps are suffering from "Trump Derangement Syndrome." "‚ÄôI‚Äôve had it‚Äô [with] hearing sick conspiracies from no-name liberal podcast hosts who clearly suffer from a severe case of Trump Derangement Syndrome," the spokesperson said. Fox News Digital also reached out to Schulz and did not receive an immediate reply. Welch has become a significant voice in Democratic circles. She has been outspoken about her belief that Democrats need to be more aggressive in their fight against Trump and his supporters. She has also hosted numerous top Democrats on her podcast, like former President Barack Obama, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, New York City mayor Zohran Mamdani, and former Vice President Kamala Harris. CLICK HERE FOR MORE COVERAGE OF MEDIA AND CULTURE CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP
news.summary: Left-wing podcasters Jennifer Welch and Angie Sullivan said they believe Trump's assassination attempt was staged, with Welch quipping she was embracing "BlueAnon" conspiracies.
news.author: Alexander Hall

news.title: Trump‚Äôs huge cash haul gives GOP chance to defy history
news.text:
Yet, money only matters if Trump chooses to deploy it, something the president has been criticized for not doing for GOP candidates in the past. Last year, there were even questions regarding whether Trump planned to endorse the 2025 Virginia GOP gubernatorial nominee, Winsome Earle-Sears.

A party strategist close to the White House was adamant that Trump would spend this year, even if history were against Republicans.

In conversations with the Washington Examiner, the source also cited Trump super PAC Make America Great Again Inc., for example, spending last year on Rep. Matt Van Epps‚Äô (R-TN) special election win in Tennessee‚Äôs 7th Congressional District.

A second Republican strategist who was granted anonymity to speak candidly quipped that the GOP would ‚Äúlove‚Äù for Trump ‚Äúto spend all this money‚Äù after the president last weekend endorsed the likes of former Sen. John Sununu for New Hampshire‚Äôs open Senate race.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we‚Äôd turn down any funding for House races, that‚Äôs for sure,‚Äù the source told the Washington Examiner. ‚ÄúBut in all seriousness, I think we‚Äôre very encouraged by the amount of money that is in the ecosystem. And that‚Äôs something that we‚Äôve never really had before.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt puts us in a really good position,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúIf we were able to win last cycle being outspent as much as we did, then imagine what we can do when we actually have the cash advantage.‚Äù

When pressed on MAGA Inc.‚Äôs plans for this year after the super PAC raised an unparalleled $289 million in 2025, spokesman Alexander Pfeiffer declined to provide specific details. 

Pfeiffer did say that thanks to Trump‚Äôs leadership, the super PAC has ‚Äúthe resources to help candidates who support President Trump‚Äôs America First agenda of securing our border, keeping our streets safe, supercharging our economy, and making life more affordable for all Americans.‚Äù

For Republican National Committee spokeswoman Kiersten Pels, Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúrecord is driving historic grassroots support and giving Republican candidates the opportunity to defy history in the midterms.‚Äù 

The RNC had $95 million cash on hand as of Dec. 31. 2025, compared to the Democratic National Committee‚Äôs $14 million, excluding the DNC‚Äôs $17 million in debt after former Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äôs failed 2024 presidential campaign.

‚ÄúDemocrats and their left-wing allies are preparing to flood the midterms with outside money, which is exactly why the RNC has built this war chest ‚Äî to go toe-to-toe with that spending, conduct targeted voter outreach, and support President Trump and our candidates nationwide,‚Äù Pels told the Washington Examiner. ‚ÄúThis momentum puts Republicans in a strong position heading into 2026.‚Äù

To that end, both Democrats and Republicans are preparing in case the Supreme Court this summer decides that the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 unconstitutionally restricts how political committees coordinate regarding campaign advertising for their party‚Äôs candidates. 

Such a Supreme Court decision, expected before July, would essentially do away with the demarcations among the different committees, solidifying Trump and Republicans‚Äô advantage. 

Nevertheless, Democratic strategist Christopher Hahn underscored that Texas Democratic state Senate candidate Taylor Rehmet last weekend defeated Trump-endorsed Leigh Wambsganss in a district that Trump won by 17 percentage points in 2024, with $380,000 to Wambsganss‚Äô $2.5 million.

‚ÄúMoney won‚Äôt save Republicans in 2026,‚Äù Hahn told the Washington Examiner.

Democratic strategist Stefan Hankin agreed, but acknowledged that Democrats need money to compete against Republicans, especially if the party does not make donors ‚Äúfeel good about opening up the checkbook‚Äù after declining to disclose its 2024 election review.

‚ÄúWe want to be able to compete in as many of those districts as humanly possible because this could be the year where we steal a bunch of seats that we really have no business winning, in theory, while Trump‚Äôs still in office,‚Äù Hankin told the Washington Examiner. ‚ÄúWe want to be able to expand the playing field as much as humanly possible and, if the money‚Äôs not there, if we‚Äôre not organized to do this, we‚Äôre going to fall short of winning the majority, at least in the House, the way things look right now.‚Äù

In response, the DNC emphasized Trump‚Äôs lack of popularity and claimed that ‚Äúthe writing is on the wall in the midterms‚Äù as many Democratic candidates in toss-up races outraised their Republican opponents. 

‚ÄúThe American people want change from the broken, billionaire-first agenda that Trump and Republicans are offering, and no matter how much rich donors spend trying to keep them in office, working families know that their bills are too high, their healthcare is too expensive, and it‚Äôs Republicans‚Äô fault,‚Äù DNC spokeswoman Nina Raneses told the Washington Examiner.

Hankin, the strategist, did echo that Democratic talking point, contending that he is ‚Äúhard pressed to come up with a way that the Republicans are going to, all of a sudden, polish that turd.‚Äù 

‚ÄúHow are they going to make voters feel better about things other than their pure base?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúYes, you need money to turn out your base, but in general, I don‚Äôt see this as being like, ‚ÄòOh, with $50 million, $100 million, you can come up with the messaging that‚Äôs going to change the hearts and minds of where Americans are given everything that‚Äôs going on.‚Äù

Despite the fundraising gap, Democrats have a slight polling advantage ahead of the midterm elections, averaging a 5-percentage-point edge over Republicans in generic congressional ballot polls, at least according to RealClearPolitics.

Republicans, too, are on defense in the House, as 14 of the 18 races Cook Political Report deems toss-ups are held by GOP lawmakers. 

But the Senate toss-up races are more evenly split between Democrats and Republicans ‚Äì the parties hold two of the four toss-up seats apiece, with the GOP having a three-seat majority even without Vice President JD Vance.

Trump has repeatedly complained about Republicans‚Äô prospects in the midterm elections as he is simultaneously poised to make weekly campaign trips.

Of last Saturday‚Äôs Texas state Senate race, Trump downplayed his participation to reporters and classified the contest as being ‚Äúlocal‚Äù and not national.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not on the ballot,‚Äù the president said. ‚ÄúSo you don‚Äôt know whether or not it‚Äôs transferable, but you put the Democrats in, you‚Äôll end up with open borders again.‚Äù

Even so, history remains against Trump and Republicans. An incumbent president‚Äôs party has not retained unilateral control of Congress in its first midterm elections since Jimmy Carter in 1978.
news.summary: An incumbent president‚Äôs party usually loses seats in the House and Senate during midterm elections, but President Donald Trump is sitting on a $375 million political war chest that Republicans believe could blunt ‚Äî or even upend‚Äî that pattern if he spends it aggressively. Trump‚Äôs fundraising committees and allied PACs have stockpiled the massive sum […]
news.author: Naomi Lim

news.title: New Poll Shows Top 2028 Presidential Candidates
news.text: A new Harvard Harris poll released this week shows the potential top candidates for 2028, with former Vice President Kamala Harris leading Democrats and Vice President JD Vance outpacing the Republican field. Newsweek reached out to political analysts via email for comment. Why It Matters Early polls have gained significance as potential contenders for the 2028 presidential election begin to emerge. Even with the election still years away, polling offers insight into candidate viability, voter sentiment and evolving party dynamics, particularly after the pivotal 2024 election cycle. What To Know According to the poll, Harris leads the pack for Democrats with 39 percent, ahead of California Governor Gavin Newsom with 30 percent, U.S. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York with 12 percent, Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro's 9 percent and Illinois Governor JB Pritzker's 7 percent. The survey shows that 4 percent say someone else. For Republicans, Vance has a commanding 53 percent of the potential vote, leading Donald Trump Jr. with 21 percent, U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio's 17 percent and former Fox News anchor Tucker Carlson's 5 percent. Three percent of poll respondents say someone else. The poll surveyed 2,000 registered voters on January 28 and January 29 and has a margin of error of 1.99 percent. The survey also shows Vance with a 38 percent favorability rating versus Rubio's 34 percent, Newsom and Ocasio-Cortez's 32 percent and Tucker Carlson's 27 percent. Outgoing Vice President Kamala Harris, left, stands with incoming Vice President JD Vance ahead of Inauguration ceremonies at the White House on January 20, 2025, in Washington, D.C. (Photo by Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images) What People Are Saying Trump, in August during a news conference when asked if Vance is the MAGA successor: ‚ÄúWell, I think most likely in all fairness, he's the vice president. I think Marco [Rubio] is also somebody that maybe would get together with JD in some form. I also think we have incredible people, some of the people on the stage right here, so it's too early obviously to talk about it but certainly he's doing a great job, and he would be probably favored at this point.‚Äú Robert Y. Shapiro, political science professor at Columbia University, to Newsweek via email in August: ‚ÄúThe Democratic primary polling is much too early and all we are seeing is name recognition for past presidential candidates and ones in the news lately in a visible way. On the Republican side, DeSantis and Rubio are damaged goods as past losers in the past Republican primaries in 2016 and 2024. Vance is on the rise by virtue of being Vice President and visible when he echoes or advocates more strongly Trump's MAGA positions and what Trump‚Äîand he‚Äîhave done. He has not been defeated in any past major election so untarnished in that respect.‚Äú What Happens Next Polls surveying Americans on potential 2028 candidates are expected to continually get released.
news.summary: Even with the election still years away, polling offers insight into candidate viability and voter sentiment.
news.author: Anna Commander

news.title: Turning Point USA announces Kid Rock as rival headliner to Bad Bunny‚Äôs Super Bowl halftime show
news.text:
The announcement from Turning Point USA, founded by Charlie Kirk and helmed by his wife Erika Kirk after his assassination, quickly drew attention from Trump officials, including Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, who wrote, ‚ÄúHey [Turning Point USA], how can [the Defense Department] get in on this?‚Äù in a post on X following the lineup‚Äôs release.

Last fall, the NFL faced backlash from Trump after tapping Bad Bunny to headline the Super Bowl LX halftime show, where the Seattle Seahawks will face off against the New England Patriots.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs absolutely ridiculous,‚Äù Trump told Newsmax of the selection of Bad Bunny, adding that he‚Äôd ‚Äúnever heard of‚Äù the artist.

The global pop star is set to make history as the first male Latin performer to headline the iconic halftime show. He has a massive global audience and was Spotify‚Äôs most streamed artist in 2025.

Bad Bunny, who recently won album of the year at the 2026 Grammy Awards, has been outspoken in his opposition to the Trump administration‚Äôs immigration crackdown and has been branded a ‚ÄúTrump hater‚Äù by MAGA influencers. He excluded the U.S. from his current world tour out of fear of ICE raids potentially targeting fans, and he endorsed former Vice President Kamala Harris during the 2024 presidential campaign.

Bad Bunny reignited that political tension Sunday night at the Grammys, using his acceptance speech to condemn the nationwide immigration crackdown.

‚ÄúBefore I say thanks to God, I‚Äôm going to say: ICE out,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not savages. We‚Äôre not animals. We‚Äôre not aliens. We are humans, and we are Americans.‚Äù

The Trump administration has intensified immigration enforcement nationwide, expanding Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations in major cities as part of a broader effort to reverse Biden-era immigration policies. The increase in raids and arrests sparked widespread protests and clashes between citizens and federal immigration agents, with some taking a violent turn, such as the shooting deaths of U.S. citizens Renee Good and Alex Pretti in Minneapolis by federal agents on separate occasions.
news.author: Finya Swai

news.title: From Bad Bunny to Billie Eilish, the Celebrities Who Took a Stand Against Trump‚Äôs Immigration Crackdown at the Grammys
news.text:
Bad Bunny‚Äôs comments come a week before he is set to headline the Super Bowl LX halftime show. 

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a terrible choice,‚Äù Trump said of the selections of Bad Bunny and Green Day, both of whom have been critical of him, to perform at the event. ‚ÄúAll it does is sow hatred. Terrible.‚Äù Speaking to right-wing podcast host Benny Johnson after the NFL‚Äôs announcement, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said that ICE agents would be "all over" the Super Bowl. "I think people should not be coming to the Super Bowl unless they're law-abiding Americans who love this country," she said.

Bad Bunny, who endorsed Kamala Harris in the 2024 presidential race, did not include any U.S. locations in his 2025-2026 tour, citing fears that ICE would raid the concert venues. 

‚ÄúPeople from the US could come here to see the show. Latinos and Puerto Ricans of the United States could also travel here, or to any part of the world,‚Äù he told i-D magazine. ‚ÄúICE could be outside. And it‚Äôs something that we were talking about and very concerned about.‚Äù
news.summary: From Bad Bunny to Billie Eilish, a number of artists made a statement against the Trump Administration's immigration crackdown.
news.author: Connor Greene

news.title: Texas Special Election: Latino Voter Shift Drives 31-Point Flip Against GOP - Bloomberg
news.text:
Big shifts among Latino voters fueled a Texas Democrat‚Äôs upset victory in a state senate district in the Fort Worth area that‚Äôs been dominated by Republicans for more than three decades, according to an analysis of results from the Jan. 31 election. 

In one precinct of the city‚Äôs heavily Latino Northside neighborhood, 81% of voters picked Democrat Taylor Rehmet, a labor union leader. In the same precinct in 2024, by contrast, 51% chose President Donald Trump, who praised Rehmet‚Äôs GOP rival before the Jan. 31 vote. Several nearby precincts backed Rehmet at 90% or more compared with about 60% for Kamala Harris in 2024. 

‚ÄúThe Hispanic vote really locked in,‚Äù said Matt Angle, founder of the Lone Star Project, a Democratic consultancy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear that they overwhelmingly supported Taylor Rehmet.‚Äù

The electoral result is leaving Republicans searching for answers as Texas voters prepare to choose a US senator this year and pick congresspeople based on redrawn maps designed to favor the GOP. With Trump‚Äôs immigration crackdown dominating headlines nationwide, Rehmet won by 14 points against conservative firebrand Leigh Wambsganss in the state senate district, which supported the president by a 17-point margin in 2024. That‚Äôs a 31-point shift. 

‚ÄúDid the Hispanic Trump voters automatically vote R?‚Äù asked Vinny Minchillo, a Texas-based Republican consultant at Glass House Strategy. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt look like it.‚Äù

Read more: Democrat Clinches Shock Win in Texas State Senate Runoff

The election was a run-off to fill a state senate seat vacated by Kelly Hancock, a more moderate Republican who left office to become the state‚Äôs acting comptroller. Wambsganss, a longtime conservative activist, has been embroiled in hot-button social issues in the district, which includes ritzy suburbs in addition to working-class areas of Fort Worth. 

‚ÄúThis was a great misread of an electorate in that district,‚Äù Minchillo said. 

Just 15% of registered voters turned out for Saturday‚Äôs election, a weekend contest that came after a brutal cold snap that made campaigning difficult. The amount either party can glean from such a unique situation is limited but the warning signs are flashing, Minchillo said. 

Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick, a Republican who endorsed Wambsganss, blamed low voter turnout and called the race a ‚Äúwake-up call for Republicans across Texas‚Äù in a post on X. John Huffman, the former mayor of Southlake, Texas, who ran against Wambsganss in the first round of voting in November, faulted her for pursuing too narrow and ideological a coalition of voters.

The GOP will soon get a chance for revenge: Rehmet will serve out the remainder of Hancock‚Äôs term, and face Wambsganss again in November for a full four-year term. 

As chief communications officer of Patriot Mobile, a cell phone company, and executive director of its political action committee, Wambsganss supported conservative school board candidates who aimed to eliminate certain race and gender teachings from classrooms and became embroiled in debates over the contents of public school libraries.

Wambsganss leaned on national Republican figures like Trump for support and appeared on Steve Bannon‚Äôs War Room show to encourage voters to turn out.

Rehmet, a US Air Force veteran and machinist at a Lockheed Martin Corp. factory in Fort Worth, eschewed culture-war issues to focus on the cost of living. He also talked about the union benefits he has received from working at the facility. 

Texas Republicans were already wary of this year‚Äôs midterm congressional elections, which will be the first to use the state‚Äôs revamped congressional districts. The new maps, which were strongly backed by Trump, are meant to net Republicans as many as five new seats in the US House of Representatives. But political analysts have cautioned that Republican leaders may have left too thin a margin if Democrats make major gains. 

The state will also vote for a US senator. The Republican incumbent, Senator John Cornyn, is locked in a close primary with Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, an outspoken conservative, and US Representative Wesley Hunt. 

Democrats, meanwhile, are choosing between Texas State Representative James Talarico, a Presbyterian seminarian who touts his crossover appeal, and US Representative Jasmine Crockett, who‚Äôs known for her fundraising skill and ability to create viral moments on social media from her confrontations with Republicans.
news.author: Joe Lovinger

news.title: Peggy Flanagan‚Äôs Chances in Minnesota Senate Race as Tina Smith Endorses
news.text: Minnesota Democrat Tina Smith endorsed Lieutenant Governor Peggy Flanagan over Representative Angie Craig to succeed her in the U.S. Senate on Monday in a race Republicans are hoping to make competitive in the midterm elections later this year. Flanagan said in a press release that she ‚Äúwould be deeply honored to carry her work forward in the United States Senate.‚Äù In a statement to Newsweek, a Craig spokesperson said the congresswoman would be ‚Äúthe best candidate to keep this seat blue.‚Äù Newsweek also reached out to the campaigns of Republicans Michele Tafoya, David Hann and Royce White for comment via email. Why It Matters Republicans are hoping to make the Senate race competitive later this year, though Minnesota has generally leaned toward Democrats in recent years. Smith opted against running for another term and chose to endorse Flanagan, viewed as the more progressive candidate, over Craig, who has built a more moderate reputation in the House of Representatives, in the Democratic primary. Minnesota has become the epicenter of the Trump administration‚Äôs ramped-up immigration enforcement. Two American citizens, Renee Nicole Good and Alex Pretti, were fatally shot by immigration officers in January amid protests in the city, and Department of Homeland Security (DHS) agents have faced growing scrutiny over their tactics in immigration operations. What To Know Smith, who previously indicated she would not endorse a candidate, unveiled her endorsement of Flanagan on X on Monday, stating that there is ‚Äúno one‚Äù she trusts more to stand with Minnesotans than the state‚Äôs lieutenant governor. ‚ÄúPeggy has served this state so well,‚Äù Smith said. ‚ÄúShe has delivered results for Minnesotans and she understands that right now what we need are fierce fighters‚Äîpeople who are willing to stand up to the status quo. People who won‚Äôt be intimidated.‚Äù Minnesota Lieutenant Governor Peggy Flanagan speaks at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago on August 19, 2024. Smith‚Äôs endorsement gives her support from a prominent Minnesota official in her primary race against Craig. She has also received support from Senator Bernie Sanders, a Vermont independent, and former Senator Al Franken, a Minnesota Democrat. Craig, meanwhile, has support from former Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. Polls have given Flanagan a lead in the primary. A Public Policy Polling survey from last month gave Flanagan a 12-point lead (40 percent to 28 percent), with nearly one-third of voters (31 percent) still being undecided about who they would support in the primary. ‚ÄúBoth candidates have net-positive favorability ratings, though Flanagan‚Äôs is much higher: 70% view her favorably while just 7% view her unfavorably for a +63 net favorability rating. Angie Craig is viewed favorably by 59% and unfavorably by 12% for a +47 net favorability rating,‚Äù the polling memo reads. It surveyed 976 likely voters from January 16-17, 2026 and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points. The latest poll from Impact Research showed a tight race but gave Flanagan a three-point lead over Craig (45 percent to 42 percent). It surveyed 600 likely voters from January 13-15, 2026 and had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Polling on the general election is more sparse. Several Republicans are running, including former Minnesota Senate Minority Leader David Hann, retired broadcaster Michele Tafoya and former NBA player Royce White, who unsuccessfully challenged Minnesota Democratic Amy Klobuchar in the 2024 Senate race. An Impact Research poll, conducted from July 8-11, 2025, showed Craig with a 4-point lead over Tafoya (49 percent to 45 percent) and Flanagan with a 3-point lead over Tafoya (48 percent to 45 percent). It surveyed 604 likely voters and had a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points. David Schultz, a professor of political science at Hamline University, told Newsweek there are a few reasons Flanagan may be leading. She may have more statewide name recognition as lieutenant governor, and the ICE surge in the state could also cause voters to embrace a more progressive politician. The ICE surge may also be galvanizing Democratic support and alienating swing voters from the GOP, Schultz said. ‚ÄúA race that I would have thought maybe if the Republicans had picked the right candidate would be competitive, I‚Äôm starting to shift it to being less competitive depending on who the Democratic candidate is also,‚Äù he said. Craig, who has represented a competitive district, is viewed as the stronger Democrat for the general election, he said, noting that Flanagan positioning herself as more progressive may not benefit her in the more conservative, rural parts of the state. Still, Democrats can win without those voters but cannot get ‚Äúblown away,‚Äù Schultz added. ‚ÄúThat becomes the question. Can Flanagan get enough support among liberal and progressive voters while potentially losing support in rural Minnesota?‚Äù he said. Minnesota last backed a Republican presidential candidate in 1972, but it has still only been light blue in recent elections. Former Vice President Kamala Harris won the state by only 4 percentage points in the 2024 presidential election. Former President Joe Biden carried it by about 7 points in 2020, while former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton won it by less than 2 points in 2016. What People Are Saying Minnesota Lieutenant Governor Peggy Flanagan said in a statement: ‚ÄúTina is an unapologetic progressive champion for working people who has delivered real results for Minnesotans all across the state. I‚Äôve learned so much from her over the years and I would be deeply honored to carry her work forward in the United States Senate.‚Äù A spokesperson for Representative Angie Craig‚Äôs campaign told Newsweek: ‚ÄúAt her core, Angie Craig is a fighter. She is the only candidate who has proven she can both win tough, competitive races against a Republican and go toe-to-toe with the Trump administration. From voting to impeach Donald Trump twice and now taking on Kristi Noem and ICE, to writing the law that capped the cost of insulin at $35 for seniors and banning members of Congress from trading stocks, Angie Craig has shown she‚Äôs the fighter Minnesotans need to hold the powerful accountable. As Republicans attack the Lt. Governor over fraud, it‚Äôs clear that the best candidate to keep this seat blue is Angie Craig.‚Äù Kyle Kondik of Sabato‚Äôs Crystal Ball wrote in a January 29 update: ‚ÄúDemocrats do have to navigate a fraud scandal that contributed to Gov. Tim Walz‚Äôs (D) recent decision not to seek a third term, and Flanagan (as a current state-level official) would be easier for Republicans to tie to that scandal. But the recent, horrific events in Minneapolis, with Renee Good and Alex Pretti being killed by federal immigration agents, are likely to nationalize the Minnesota races in favor of Democrats, and Sen. Amy Klobuchar‚Äôs (D-MN) entrance into the gubernatorial race is also likely to be helpful to the eventual Democratic Senate nominee.‚Äù What Happens Next Forecasters give Democrats an advantage. Both the Cook Political Report and Sabato‚Äôs Crystal Ball classify the race as Likely Democratic. The primary is set for August 11, 2026, according to the Minnesota Secretary of State‚Äôs office.
news.summary: Smith backed Lt. Governor Flanagan over Representative Angie Craig in the Democratic primary to replace her on Monday.
news.author: Andrew Stanton

news.title: Laughter
news.text:
In Time Enough for Love, Robert Heinlein dropped a significant remark about laughter. ‚ÄúWhen apes learn to laugh, they‚Äôll be people.‚Äù Laughter is what makes us human. But there are different kinds of laughter, and different ways of being human. The best kind of laughter reinforces our deeper or richer humanity, creating a sense of empathy with others. Other types of laughter, on the other hand, create division and express what we recognize as inhumanity. 

Some laughter responds to clever wordplay, sharp irony, unexpected consequences, and, of course, a touch of warmth; it reflects shared cohesion or mutual understanding. Other kinds of laughter violate these norms and criteria, suggesting a propensity for causing discomfort or harm. Such laughter is an expression of malevolence and sadistic violence, of mental unbalance or even outright madness.

Nervous laughter and phatic laughter are a rather different genre of expostulation, having nothing to do with humor or aggression. They are forms of deflecting attention from ill-at-ease-ness or what we might call flow-stall, that is, when a thought or phrase embarrassingly fails to complete itself via misspeaks, accidental interruptions, and brain freeze.

The timbre or quality of laughter is also important. The laughter of certain public figures is famously a symptom of some form of cerebral vertigo. One thinks of the high-pitched shriek of Tucker Carlson, a cross between the screech of a howler monkey in distress and a badly oiled gate hinge. There is definitely something wrong there. Kamala Harris for her part has become notorious for what has been described as a cackle, a disquieting morphic meld between the creepy vocalizations of a hyena and the readle-eak of a grackle, with maybe a chicken thrown into the pot for good measure. We should be thankful she does not yelp, bark, roar or grunt, or the force of her laughter might then be threatening rather than comical or immiserating. I have a friend who laughs like a magpie in a belfry, which makes it impossible to take even the good things he says seriously, and compels me to wonder about his internal balance. Nail-on-chalkboard laughter is often taken as a symptom of incipient derangement, and perhaps rightly so.

We have many qualifiers for different kinds of laughter: hearty laughter, sarcastic laugher, cruel laughter, evil laughter, and so on. The heh heh of the Grinch stealing Christmas signifies the joy of causing pain or discomfort, the gritch of motiveless sadism. The guffaw or vocal explosives of Mafia goon laughter in films indicates the pleasure of subcortical ferocity. The peals and arc-like gales or insidious titters is the stock in trade of the infernal demon. The belly-laugh of the good-natured companion is the Falstaffian sonic surround of camaraderie. One thinks of the Jewish expression, carried over into many other languages: das mentsh trakht un got lakht (man proposes and God laughs). But what is the laughter of God? Is it affectionate? Is it imperial? Here we admit our ignorance.

In her study of Jewish humor, No Joke, Ruth Wisse speaks of laughter‚Äôs salvific properties, a special instance of humor that releases a special kind of laughter. Jewish jokes and the laughter they provoke, typically self-deprecating, have multiple functions: they are expressions of humility and modesty; a recognition of the absurdity of the world, and a coping mechanism ‚Äútransmuting humiliation, subjugation, and dread into funniness.‚Äù It‚Äôs a bad joke that induces a good joke, the laughter of incredulity and the preposterous fun of verbal, half-unserious self-immolation. It is redemptive laughter in the midst of adversity. As Freud marvelled in Jokes and their Relation to the Unconscious, ‚ÄúI do not know whether there are many other instances of a people making fun to such a degree of its own character.‚Äù 

One cannot go any further unless one asks what all these species of laughter have in common. This brings up the more genetic question about laughter, in short, what is this weird, cascading outburst in the first place? We are all, at least to some extent, Tucker Carlson or Kamala Harris. When one becomes clinically aware of laughter, one realizes the absolute eerieness of our condition as something other than mere animals capable of some degree of thought. 

Gelotology‚Äîwhich AI confuses with Gelatology or the making of ice cream, and which is unintentionally funny in itself‚Äîis the science of laughter, a recognized field of study featuring many excellent researchers. In my estimation, one of the best books on the subject is Scott Weems‚Äô HA! Weems views laughter as arising from a contest or squabble in the brain‚Äîtension in the mind is probably a better description‚Äîaccompanied by surprise and joy at the moment of reconciliation. 

Max Nieuwdorp in The Power of Hormones provides a clinical analysis of endocrinological paradigms largely in the support of laughter in the quarrel between happy endorphins and angry cortisols. 

William Fry in Sweet Madness investigates humor and laughter from a transactional standpoint, as something that is most effective and vivid in social contexts to establish a feeling of complicity or simple entertainment for a society of equals that binds them together. He does not, unfortunately, examine the mechanics of laughter in profound detail. 

In The Act of Creation, Arthur Koestler sees laughter as arising from a ‚Äúcollision of matrices‚Äù or frameworks that release tension in staccato gusts of breath, a clash of referential schemata or cognitive grids he calls ‚Äúbisociative events.‚Äù It is a creative leap ‚Äúthat gives rise to new and startling perceptions and glimpses of reality.‚Äù Laughter detaches us from disturbing feelings, releasing stress or agitation or psychic pressure in a burst of innocent humor, followed by an access of relief. These puffs, blasts and eruptions of air and CO2 from the lungs, this collapsing diaphragm allowing for a fresh intake of oxygen, helps to restore equilibrium after the stress of what we might call anxious patience, waiting for the punch line, hovering before the contrast represented by the unexpected or the eventual and yet sudden fulfillment of desire. The hidden metaphor is that of a tightly coiled spring.

Like the flow of tears, which no other creature shares, and which can be intimately associated with laughter and caused by the same phenomena, laughter is both a mechanism‚Äîanalogically, a tightly wound spring packed with kinetic energy‚Äîand a spiritual or pneumatic (quite literally) mystery of attitude, flair and conscious anticipation, a numinous quality that connects us to something other than the physical. Nobody really knows what it is, but it is surely an imprint of something alien and unsettling. 

Spend a little time just observing oneself or others caught up in a snort or a squall of laughter, the throwing back of the head, the shaking of the physique, the cataract of clipped or amorphous sound that has no relation to speech, and simply register what is occurring. One should feel a state of bafflement infused with self-consciousness‚Äîand at the same time discover something rather astounding about ourselves. The bizarre, alveolar expulsion of breath, which seems frankly grotesque when we become aware of it, is an uncanny mix of the natural and the unnatural, a sign that we are both in and out of the predictable, customary world. Whether benign or foolish or spiteful, it resembles a form of dyskinesia, the flux of involuntary gestures, almost a kind of disorder.

But laughter may also be the incursion of the transcendent realm or dimension, of the strangely noetic, whether admirable or discreditable, into the material element of our being. The phenomenon comes from elsewhere, as if from a region of existence that Saint Paul describes in his letter to the Ephesians as the realm of the Spirit, that is, of Powers and Fiends from whom we descend in equal parts. It is not an abstract concept but an authentic reality. Angels sing. Demons howl. And we laugh. 

Editor‚Äôs Note: Support and follow PJ Media‚Äôs coverage of leftist corruption and other key news in this new year. Join PJ Media VIP and use promo code FIGHT to get 60% off your membership.
news.author: David Solway

news.title: Headlines Are Calling the Melania Movie a Surprise Box-Office ‚ÄúSuccess.‚Äù Don‚Äôt Believe Them.
news.text:
Third-place opening weekends are not usually the stuff of box-office headlines, but on Saturday, you couldn‚Äôt pick up your phone without reading that Melania, Brett Ratner‚Äôs gauzy, glad-handing portrait of the first lady, was doing much better than expected. Deadline called its opening the strongest for a documentary in a decade, and the New York Times wrote that its $8 million opening was 60 percent above industry predictions. By Sunday, however, the latter number had been revised drastically downward, from $8 million to barely over $7 million, and as for the former statistic, it only holds if you don‚Äôt categorize concert movies as nonfiction, since it‚Äôs nowhere in the ballpark of The Eras Tour‚Äôs $123 million.

In the days leading up to Melania‚Äôs release, Bluesky was filled with gloating screenshots of ticketing sites showing mostly empty theaters, not to mention a widely recirculated Craigslist post purportedly offering $50 to anyone who attended a screening. (The post was real, although there‚Äôs no indication that the offer was genuine.) But it doesn‚Äôt seem far-fetched, even with Donald Trump‚Äôs poll numbers cratering, that a small fraction of his 77 million voters would turn out for the film‚Äîeither out of genuine interest or simply as a show of support‚Äîand although there wasn‚Äôt a single theater showing Melania in the city of Philadelphia, the Friday matinee I attended in a South Jersey suburb was mostly full.

The audience‚Äîperhaps 70 people or so‚Äîwasn‚Äôt especially vocal, although there was a smattering of applause at the closing credits, and one person repeatedly clapped during the footage of Trump‚Äôs second inauguration. But I heard appreciative murmurs on the way out, and one person said, loud enough for the entire theater to hear, ‚ÄúThat was a good movie.‚Äù Critics, perhaps needless to say, did not agree: Metacritic characterizes their response as ‚Äúoverwhelming dislike,‚Äù with one particularly scathing pan calling it ‚Äúa gilded trash remake of The Zone of Interest.‚Äù

What struck me most powerfully about Melania is how overwhelmingly dull it is. As Slate‚Äôs Heather Schwedel pointed out, the media landscape is teeming with low-stakes celebrity docs, skin-deep forays into their personal lives that offer a carefully managed sense of intimacy. But even by the standards of those personal-brand advertorials, Ratner‚Äôs movie is an utter bust. If its purpose is to offer an unprecedented glimpse into its subject‚Äôs humanity, the only conclusion to be drawn is that its subject has no humanity to uncover.

There is, of course, another theory about Melania‚Äôs purpose: that it is, effectively, a bribe. As one documentary expert told the Times, the $40 million Amazon paid to acquire the film has ‚Äúno correlation to the marketplace,‚Äù and though the camera doesn‚Äôt linger on company founder Jeff Bezos, you can clearly make him out on the dais during Trump‚Äôs inauguration, mere feet from the woman his company paid $28 million of that $40 million for her participation. It‚Äôs true that Melania‚Äôs opening weekend is unusually large for a (non-concert) documentary, but that‚Äôs in large part because most documentaries don‚Äôt open with $35 million in marketing. In Hollywood, there‚Äôs a term for what happens when a movie you‚Äôve spent $75 million on opens with $7 million in box office: It‚Äôs a flop.

Amazon executives, who vastly outbid competing offers from Disney and Netflix, have insisted it will find its real audience when it‚Äôs released on Prime Video in a few weeks, and they wouldn‚Äôt be the first streaming company to lose money on a theatrical release in the name of building their subscriber base. But coming the same week as the Bezos-owned Washington Post announced plans to gut its coverage of international affairs, along with sports and local issues, it‚Äôs hard not to imagine the other uses that $75 million could have been put to.

Although Melania ends with a typed-out list of the first lady‚Äôs purported political accomplishments‚Äîsome of which, like the claim that she is the first presidential spouse to contribute the ‚Äúcore elements‚Äù of an executive order, seem unlikely to stand up to rigorous fact-checking‚Äîthe movie spends precious little time dramatizing them. There‚Äôs a brief Zoom with Brigitte Macron about joint messaging on cyberbullying, and a meeting with Aviva Siegel, a former Hamas hostage whose husband was still being held captive. But Ratner and his legendary cinematographer, Dante Spinotti, spend more time watching her hash out the hemline of her inaugural dress and fretting over the five-hour window the Trumps have to move their furnishings into the White House after Joe Biden vacates it. Even when she‚Äôs performing quasi-official duties, like attending Jimmy Carter‚Äôs funeral, her focus never widens beyond herself. Carter‚Äôs funeral happens to fall on the first anniversary of her mother‚Äôs death, and while it‚Äôs natural that the personal loss would strike her more acutely, it‚Äôs striking that her voiceover, which was presumably scripted and recorded long after the fact, never spares so much as a thought for the late president.

That lack of self-awareness runs all through Melania. Ratner is unable to coax so much as a flicker of feeling from his immaculately composed, dead-eyed subject, often jockeying to catch a glimpse of her as she vanishes into an elevator or an SUV, surrounded by a forbidding phalanx of Secret Service agents. And when he finally does manage to make his way into the passenger seat, he sounds less like a documentarian probing his subject than a nervous date making awkward small talk. (He doesn‚Äôt even follow up when he asks Melania for her favorite recording artists and she responds with Michael Jackson, settling for getting her to sing a few notes of ‚ÄúBillie Jean.‚Äù) The movie is threaded with pricey but inapt music cues, like the doomy strains of ‚ÄúGimme Shelter‚Äù that accompany its opening drone shots, although Ratner has enough presence of mind to mute the lyrics of ‚ÄúEverybody Wants to Rule the World‚Äù as Melania rolls toward the inaugural ball. (The Stones‚Äô ‚Äúrape, murder‚Äù stays in.) After Melania lights a candle for her late mother at St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral, Ratner blithely cuts from an upward-gazing shot of its Gothic exterior to the gleaming black obelisk of Trump Tower, which would be a blasphemous equation even if it wasn‚Äôt scored to Aretha Franklin‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmazing Grace.‚Äù (Cinephiles may have similar objections to the way Ratner ganks excerpts from the scores for Midnight Express and Phantom Thread.)

But while Melania tells us almost nothing about its ostensible subject, it is, at least in brief moments, a fascinating study of sycophancy. In the lead-up to the inauguration, which provides the closest thing the movie has to a narrative arc, Melania is surrounded by designers and decorators and event planners, each more obsequious than the next. Herv√© Pierre, the designer charged with making and modifying her inaugural gown, fields even impossible requests with an eager nod, sights set squarely on having his work preserved in the Smithsonian, while the functionary assigned to planning the candlelight ball on the eve of the inauguration makes a big show of unveiling the color of the invitations: ‚ÄúNot even the president has seen this,‚Äù he confides, as if the particular shade of red were a closely guarded secret.

Trump himself makes only a few appearances, and while it would strain the word to say their back-and-forths display anything like intimacy, he‚Äôs clearly more attuned to the cameras than she is. But the only unguarded moment in all of Melania comes from his former opponent. As Trump prepares to assume the presidency, the cameras capture Joe Biden emerging from a room behind the dais. He‚Äôs followed by Kamala Harris, who wears a look that‚Äôs difficult to describe, a combination of dread and anxiety and the desire to, at that precise moment, be anywhere other than where she is. In the theater behind me, I swore I could feel the audience savoring her discomfort, or maybe I just imagined the hint of a chuckle. But it felt, for the first and only time, as if I was watching something real.
news.summary: The first lady has entered her flop era.
news.author: Sam Adams

news.title: Donald Trump Threatens to Sue Trevor Noah Over Epstein Grammys Joke
news.text:
In his Truth Social post, Trump called the Grammy ceremony ‚Äúvirtually unwatchable‚Äù and threatened legal action against Noah: ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be sending my lawyers to sue this poor, pathetic, talentless, dope of an M.C.‚Äù
Noah returned to host the Grammys for a sixth consecutive time on CBS. During the ceremony, Noah shared that it would be the Grammys‚Äô last one on CBS‚Äîthe event is moving to Disney+ and Hulu‚Äîand his last appearance as the show‚Äôs host as well, at least for the foreseeable future. After this disclosure, Noah exhibited a bit more of a devil-may-care attitude with his jokes, aiming one about the coveted song-of-the-year award at Trump and his well-documented relationship with deceased convicted sex offender Epstein.
That prize, said Noah, ‚Äúis a Grammy that every artist wants almost as much as Trump wants Greenland. Which makes sense because Epstein‚Äôs island is gone. He needs a new one to hang out with Bill Clinton.‚Äù After the joke got a sustained laugh, Noah noted again that this was his last ceremony as host; as such, he had nothing to lose. (Both Trump and Clinton have denied having any connection to Epstein‚Äôs crimes.)
Needless to say, Trump was not a fan of the joke‚Äîor of Noah‚Äôs hosting ability writ large. ‚ÄúThe Grammy Awards are the WORST, virtually unwatchable!‚Äù he posted on Truth Social at 1:01 a.m. He then shouted out CBS‚Äînow run by David Ellison, the son of billionaire longtime Trump supporter Larry Ellison‚Äîfor no longer airing the Grammys going forward, writing that the network was ‚Äúlucky not to have this garbage litter their airwaves any longer.‚Äù
Trump turned his attention to Noah while also getting in a dig at another comedian enemy of his: Jimmy Kimmel. ‚ÄúThe host, Trevor Noah, whoever he may be, is almost as bad as Jimmy Kimmel at the Low Ratings Academy Awards,‚Äù Trump wrote, claiming to be unfamiliar with Noah‚Äôs work. For what it‚Äôs worth, Trump pulled the same move with album-of-the-year winner and Super Bowl halftime headliner Bad Bunny in October, claiming that he had ‚Äúnever heard of‚Äù the global Latin-music superstar before ripping his Super Bowl selection apart.
Trump then turned his attention to Noah‚Äôs insinuation that he had spent time on Epstein‚Äôs island. ‚ÄúNoah said, INCORRECTLY about me, that Donald Trump and Bill Clinton spent time on Epstein Island. WRONG!!!‚Äù Trump continued. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt speak for Bill, but I have never been to Epstein Island, nor anywhere close, and until tonight‚Äôs false and defamatory statement, have never been accused of being there, not even by the Fake News Media.‚Äù
Ultimately, Trump threatened to get litigious with Noah for his Greenland crack. ‚ÄúNoah, a total loser, better get his facts straight, and get them straight fast,‚Äù Trump added. ‚ÄúIt looks like I‚Äôll be sending my lawyers to sue this poor, pathetic, talentless, dope of an M.C., and suing him for plenty$.‚Äù
Considering how regularly comedians joke about Trump and his Epstein connection‚Äîsee, for instance, any given episode of Saturday Night Live of late‚Äîit‚Äôs a bit surprising for Trump to react so strongly to Noah‚Äôs dig at the Grammys. Then again, it seems Trump has become emboldened by his recent wins against the media. In 2024, ABC News settled a defamation lawsuit with Trump for $15 million over anchor George Stephanopoulos‚Äôs claim that Trump had been found ‚Äúliable for rape‚Äù in his E. Jean Carroll case. (Trump was technically found liable for sexual abuse; he has denied the allegation.) Paramount reached a $16 million settlement with Trump last year to resolve a 2024 lawsuit against CBS regarding the editing of a 60 Minutes interview with Kamala Harris ahead of the election. Trump mentioned both victories in his Truth Social post: ‚ÄúAsk Little George Slopadopolus, and others, how that all worked out. Also ask CBS!‚Äù
Trump ended his rant with a foreboding message to the South African comedian: ‚ÄúGet ready Noah, I‚Äôm going to have some fun with you!‚Äù
Vanity Fair has reached out to Noah for comment.
news.summary: While hosting the Grammys on Sunday, the former Daily Show host made a dig implying that Trump and Bill Clinton had hung out on Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs notorious island. Trump laid into Noah on Truth Social: ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be sending my lawyers.‚Äù
news.author: Chris Murphy

news.title: Lemon Laws
news.text:
He was released without bail, and maintains he was acting in the capacity of a journalist.

I can't help but notice a difference in how conservatives, both journalists and civilians, are treated versus the way Lemon has been treated.

Just last January, independent journalists David Daleiden and Sandra Merritt finally settled a yearslong case with the state of California after then-Attorney General Kamala Harris charged the two with multiple crimes in relation to their reporting that exposed Planned Parenthood illegally selling the body parts of aborted babies. That process lasted almost a decade, during which the pair were fined hundreds of thousands of dollars by the courts, in addition to any legal fees they racked up defending themselves. Merritt had to post $75,000 for bail in the California case, and I'm sure Daleiden did, too, although I cannot find a credible number on that. To top it off, the state of California lied after Daleiden and Merritt entered their "no contest" plea deals, and California Attorney General Rob Bonta secured a ‚Äúfelony conviction‚Äù of the two. Instead, under the plea deal, Daleiden and Merritt received "no jail time, no fines, no admission of wrongdoing, and no probation," according to the National Catholic Register.

That's an admission the state of California didn't have a case against the pair, and a judge even ruled in 2019 that only nine of the 15 charges could be brought to trial.

When Steven Baker covered the events of January 6 as a journalist, he was not informed of the charges against him by the Biden DOJ until he turned himself in. Baker did, and he was placed in handcuffs and leg irons and transported by armed agents. Some media outlets cheered Baker's arrest, with places like The Hill asking if Baker was a "journalist, advocate, or advocacy journalist."

NEW: Blaze News Investigative Journalist, Steve Baker Arrested by FBI for January 6 Riot Reporting.The federal agencies are weaponized by the government to go after anyone who dares to report the truth. pic.twitter.com/UOM2KoE4Mh‚Äî I Meme Therefore I Am üá∫üá∏ (@ImMeme0) March 1, 2024

Baker pled guilty to the charges in November, 2024. He was later pardoned by President Trump.

But the process was the punishment.

The same can be said for Mark Houck, the pro-life husband and father who woke up to the Biden FBI raiding his home on the morning of September 23, 2022. The agents were armed and pointed their weapons at the Houck family before taking Mark into custody. Like Lemon, Houck was charged under the FACE Act after confronting an abusive abortion activist outside of a clinic in 2021 ‚Äî Houck was not tried in state court, and the activist's lawsuit against Houck failed, too. But the Biden DOJ wanted to put Houck behind bars for 11 years and $350,000 in fines. Houck was acquitted in January 2023.

Nearly a dozen other pro-life activists faced similar charges under the FACE Act. Several, including Jean Marshall and Joan Bell, were convicted under the FACE Act. So was Paula Harlow, who was convicted for praying in the doorway of an abortion clinic. She was sentenced to two years in prison at the age of 76, with the judge mockingly telling Harlow to "pray" over her health concerns.

Not one person currently screaming about the FACE Act being used to rightly charge Don Lemon and his pals cared a bit about Daleiden, Merritt, Baker, Houck, and the rest. Many of them cheered those prosecutions, because their preferred ox (abortion) was being gored or, in Baker's case, their false narratives were being exposed.

Meanwhile, Don Lemon hasn't been asked to surrender his passport (he even gets to take his summer vacation to France), and he showed up at the Grammys last night, too.

Don Lemon steps out at the Grammys days after being taken into custody by federal agents. https://t.co/BK9E6u63mEüì∏ Getty pic.twitter.com/KUuwwPlctN‚Äî TMZ (@TMZ) February 2, 2026

Have you spotted the difference? Lemon gets to go about his life as if he did nothing wrong. Meanwhile, the lives of other journalists and average Americans are thrown into chaos, using the full weight of the federal government. And I suspect if Democrats get back into power, we'll see more Bakers and Houcks than we will Lemons.

 "For my friends, everything. For my enemies, the law."
news.author: Amy Curtis

news.title: How Nicki Minaj Took MAGA by the Hand
news.text:
‚ÄúShe reached out to me and she said she‚Äôs been praying about it,‚Äù Bruesewitz said last week, ‚Äúand it‚Äôs been on her heart that she wants to speak out.‚Äù
In November, Bruesewitz and Minaj strode into the United Nations together, with paparazzi on hand to document his neatly cropped suit and her dramatic fur coat. Following an introduction from UN ambassador Mike Waltz, Minaj and Adonu appeared at an event about Nigeria. After Minaj joined Erika Kirk onstage at Turning Point USA‚Äôs annual convention the following month, JD Vance described her comments at the event as ‚Äúreally profound.‚Äù The emergence of MAGA‚Äôs new, preeminent pop-culture avatar reached its apex on Wednesday, when Minaj stood palm in palm with Trump at an event for a new savings and investment program for children, her long nails grazing over the president‚Äôs much-studied hand makeup.
From one vantage, it is unlikely that the majority of the Barbz, the devout community of Minaj fans who are surely aware of her prior criticisms of Trump on social media, would have seen such an arc coming. But in Bruesewitz‚Äôs view, the alliance was no great surprise, nor did it warrant the eyebrows raised across the mainstream press. ‚ÄúI think they are very similar people,‚Äù he says, noting that the rapper and the president were both raised in Queens. And then there was what he saw as their outsider status, a sense of persecution perpetuated by a sweeping, Democrat-aligned entertainment and media apparatus‚Äîhe emphasized that Minaj has never won a Grammy.
‚ÄúNew York Times, CNN, MSNBC,‚Äù Bruesewitz says, ‚Äúthey treat Nicki the way that Trump is treated by those places.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe hate or what people have to say, it does not affect me at all,‚Äù Minaj said as Trump smiled behind her on Wednesday. ‚ÄúIt actually motivates me to support him more.‚Äù It was, despite the online outcry, a natural attitudinal fit: Her career has been powered in part by her appetite for protracted public feuds with her fellow female rappers, Megan Thee Stallion and Cardi B among them, both of whom endorsed Kamala Harris during the 2024 campaign. ‚ÄúYou look pretty good behind the seal, by the way,‚Äù Bruesewitz told Minaj during a fireside chat. ‚ÄúI must admit: Your competition, which really isn‚Äôt competition, didn‚Äôt really look good behind the seal when they were with Kamala Harris.‚Äù
Trump‚Äôs affiliation with hip-hop more broadly dates back to his time in New York‚Äôs nightclubs during the ‚Äô90s, a history evoked by his answers to recent questions about whether he would consider pardoning Sean ‚ÄúDiddy‚Äù Combs. After inspiring countless rap lyrics in the decades to follow, his 2024 campaign advisers figured they could lean into the outlaw credibility accrued by the criminal charges he faced and the attempt on his life. As Bruesewitz spent time in Los Angeles in recent years, building ties with entertainers, athletes, and influencers, he started talking with Amber Rose, the model and hip-hop personality who dated Kanye West before marrying Wiz Khalifa. (She and the Pittsburgh rapper divorced in 2016.) Rose, who announced her support for Trump shortly before speaking at the Republican National Convention during the campaign, started adding Bruesewitz to group chats with her rapper friends and introduced him to Minaj.
At the RNC, Rose also met Florida congresswoman Anna Paulina Luna. At 36, Luna, a former model, has described herself as ‚Äúone of the OG politicos on Instagram‚Äù‚Äîit was Charlie Kirk, with his own emphasis on the importance of social media in politics, who first encouraged her to pursue this path‚Äîand since her election in 2023, has helped foster ties between Republicans and rappers including 50 Cent and Tory Lanez. ‚ÄúWhen they tried to take [Trump‚Äôs] mugshot,‚Äù Luna said last week, ‚Äúthat actually was the biggest backfire in American history.‚Äù
Rose eventually put Luna in touch with Minaj as well, and in July, months before any of Minaj‚Äôs recent Trump-affiliated appearances, she and the congresswoman were tweeting at each other about Minaj‚Äôs claim that an associate of a rival‚Äôs record label was threatening her.
‚ÄúPlease text my cell,‚Äù Luna wrote. ‚ÄúI will forward this to law enforcement immediately.‚Äù
Luna declined to go into details about ‚Äúpotentially illegal activity‚Äù that she said Minaj was facing, but the union was solidified: They talked backstage at Minaj‚Äôs Turning Point appearance.
‚ÄúObviously we‚Äôve seen that Hollywood has increasingly, for those that are conservative,‚Äù Luna says, ‚Äúbeen more accepting and changed its perspective.‚Äù She believes that Minaj‚Äôs Republican affinities signal a broader shift in the works.
‚ÄúI look forward to seeing who else comes out as a conservative,‚Äù Luna says. ‚ÄúI hear there‚Äôs a lot.‚Äù
Minaj sat by Trump at the premiere of Melania on Thursday night, and Katie Miller will release a podcast interview with her on Tuesday. As it happens, Bruesewitz‚Äôs wedding took place on Saturday at Trump‚Äôs National Doral golf resort in Miami, and the guest list demonstrated some of the overlap between MAGA‚Äôs A-list‚ÄîDon Jr., Karoline Leavitt‚Äîand the entertainment world‚ÄîMike Tyson, St. Louis rapper Sexyy Red. When Rose discussed the occasion during a recent livestream, she said that during the 2024 campaign, she and Minaj would talk about their mutual support of Trump, but Minaj kept it quiet at the time. Now the secret was out.
‚ÄúShe‚Äôs sitting next to me at the wedding,‚Äù Rose explained.
news.summary: Jarring as the alliance has seemed, it grew from a certain attitudinal resonance between the rapper and the president, each raised in Queens and bearing a sense of persecution, as well as some increasingly overlapping social circles.
news.author: Dan Adler

news.title: CNN Data Guru Hits Trump With Major Midterm Warning After Humiliating GOP Defeat
news.text:
CNN data guru Harry Enten has issued a severe warning to President Donald Trump after Republicans were thrashed in a special election in the heart of MAGA country. 

Democratic candidate Taylor Rehmet, 33, swept to victory in Texas State Senate District 9, a ruby-red district that Trump handily won by 17 points in 2024, in a state Senate runoff on Saturday.

Speaking on CNN News Central, Enten called out GOP Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, who largely dismissed special elections as ‚Äúquirky‚Äù in a post on X, saying he felt Republicans needed only to be ‚Äúclear-eyed about the political environment heading into the midterms.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat happened in Texas 9, it didn‚Äôt just swing to the left, it took a rocket ship to the left,‚Äù Enten said, suggesting it could be part of a wider trend. ‚ÄúMy goodness gracious, the Texas 9 Senate district election margins; this was a district that Donald Trump won by 17 points in 2024.

‚ÄúFor the Democratic candidate in the special election on Saturday‚Äîhello, won it by 14 points. That‚Äôs an over 30-point shift to the left. Any Republican‚Äîunlike Ron DeSantis, who doesn‚Äôt take this seriously‚Äîthey should realize that this is very perilous. They ignore this result at their own peril. Ron DeSantis is right to say, ‚ÄòHey, special elections can be quirky,‚Äô but this ain‚Äôt no quirk.‚Äù

The victory saw Rehmet win 57 percent of the runoff vote to overcome Republican Leigh Wambsganss, despite her having Trump‚Äôs endorsement and what the Texas Tribune described as a ‚Äúfurious funding push in a bid to tilt the election in [her] favor in the final days.‚Äù

When it was raised that the storm that gripped much of the U.S. last week could have been to blame for the special election‚Äôs result, Enten was unconvinced. ‚ÄúNo, that ain‚Äôt no ice storm,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf you ignore this, you‚Äôre going to ice yourself out of a majority come the midterms.‚Äù

He continued, ‚ÄúSo, you know, you see this 31-point shift to the left, right? If this were just one election, that would be one thing. But it‚Äôs the slew of special elections that together paint a picture, and it‚Äôs a picture that Democrats should love and a picture that Republicans should be really worried about, because what are we talking about here? 

‚ÄúThe average 2025-2026 special elections Democrats are doing, get this, 12 points better‚Äî12 points better‚Äîthan Kamala Harris did in 2024. And that was a state special election that happened in Texas on Saturday. If you look at the federal special elections, this 12 points is actually north of 15 points on average,‚Äù Enten continued.

Enten said that it paints a gloomy picture for the GOP heading into the midterms.
news.summary:
