news.title: Why Netflix‚Äôs deal with the Obamas could put its bid to buy Warner Bros. at risk
news.text:
Netflix heads to Washington, DC, this week to testify about the streamer‚Äôs proposed acquisition of Warner Bros. Discovery ‚Äî a couple weeks after President Trump posted an opinion piece on Truth Social headlined, ‚ÄúStop the Netflix Cultural Takeover.‚Äù

Sources tell Page Six Hollywood that besides Trump wanting his ally Larry Ellison to win the bid for the famed studio, another reason the president is sour on the Netflix deal is, in part, because it‚Äôs been the home of the Obamas, insiders say.

The Obamas signed an exclusive deal with Netflix for their Higher Ground production company in 2018, during Trump‚Äôs first term. In 2019, Trump called for a financial investigation into the Obamas‚Äô Netflix pact, asking Democrats to ‚Äúlook at the Obama book deal, or the ridiculous Netflix deal.‚Äù Insiders tell us that the Obamas‚Äô deal with Netflix remains a major sticking point for Trump. ‚ÄúIf Trump does put his fingers on the scale for Paramount, it‚Äôs going to be because of the Obamas,‚Äù said a source.

However, sources tell us, the Obamas no longer have an overall deal at Netflix ‚Äî and have also been making projects for other studios. But that hasn‚Äôt stopped those in the MAGA orbit from calling for Trump to block the Warner Bros. takeover.

There‚Äôs no love lost between the former first couple and Trump ‚Äî particularly after Michelle skipped Trump‚Äôs second inauguration, even as Barack seemed friendlier with the Donald. ‚ÄúShe showed up reluctantly for the election. They were united, but she doesn‚Äôt have to unify around [Trump]. She doesn‚Äôt have to say anything. Her absence speaks volumes,‚Äù an insider told Page Six at the time. (Barack attended the inauguration and was seen smiling and chatting with the president at Jimmy Carter‚Äôs funeral while Michelle also stayed away on a Hawaiian vacay.)

Conservatives have long been critical of Netflix‚Äôs programming for pushing progressive themes.

Adding to the intrigue, Netflix CEO Ted Sarandos‚Äô wife, Hollywood insider Nicole Avant, was named by Obama as Ambassador to the Bahamas. Then again, Netflix has been cozying up to Trump, including Sarandos. An insider told The Post‚Äôs Charlie Gasparino, ‚ÄúThat meeting was key to getting our side of the story, how the antitrust implications are overblown‚Ä¶ It lasted two hours because Ted (Sarandos) and the president got along great.‚Äù

Nicole is the daughter of late philanthropist Jacqueline Avant and famed music exec Clarence Avant. She‚Äôs also a top Democratic donor and raised more than $500M as a bundler for Obama‚Äôs campaign in 2012. She has also raised money for Kamala Harris, Joe Biden and California Gov. Gavin Newsom. (Then again, she told Dems after Trump won, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be whining all the time.‚Äù)

Trump has said he‚Äôll play an active role in how the White House views WBD‚Äôs future as it houses his nemesis news channel CNN, as well as HBO‚Äôs programming and other assets.

A Netflix rep did not comment.
news.summary: Sources say that another reason Trump is sour on the Netflix deal is because it's been the home of the Obamas.
news.author: Ian Mohr,mliss1578

news.title: Bill Maher Torches Virtue-Signaling Lefty Celebs For Ditching Causes Once They're Not The 'Current Thing'
news.text:
After another awards show shitshow of anti-Trump-ism at The Grammy's, Bill Maher has had it with Hollywood‚Äôs relentless virtue signaling, and during his latest monologue on his HBO show Real Time with Bill Maher.

And he really let the glitterati have it. 

Maher, a leftist liberal himself, began with mock enthusiasm for the endless parade of political posturing that now infects every red-carpet event.

‚ÄúHow about everybody drop the politics for a couple of hours,‚Äù he quipped, ‚Äúand just enjoy these happy, dopey celebrations of show business?‚Äù 

At last month‚Äôs Golden Globes awards, a number of celebrities wore small, stylized pins tied to the Renee Good shooting, including vague slogans like and 

"Of course, this is for the mother who was murdered by an ICE agent, and it's really sad. I know people are out marching and all today, and we need to speak up," actress Wanda Sykes told Variety on the red carpet before the award show. "We need to be out there and shut this rogue government down, because it's just awful what they're doing to people." 

Maher, who was also at the event, recalled a reporter asking him why he wasn‚Äôt wearing a lapel pin at the Golden Globes last month for the shooting of Renee Good in Minneapolis. At the time, he said, ‚ÄúWell, it was a terrible thing that happened, and it shouldn‚Äôt have happened, and if they didn‚Äôt act like such thugs, it wouldn‚Äôt have had to happen. But I don‚Äôt need to wear a pin about it.‚Äù He then added, ‚ÄúIf I had the chance to think about it, my answer would be exactly the same.‚Äù

Maher then skewered the hysteria that followed his comments at the Golden Globes, where critics accused him of ‚Äúrefusing to join Golden Globes activism.‚Äù 

His reply dripped with sarcasm.

He mocked the self-congratulation behind Hollywood‚Äôs symbolic gestures. ‚ÄúI hope I didn‚Äôt spoil the perfect record of pins and ribbons solving all the world‚Äôs problems. You can‚Äôt name a problem, from guns to AIDS to bullying to breast cancer, that still exists after people wore a ribbon for it‚Äîexcept all of them.‚Äù

The old liberal crusaders took a hit next. ‚ÄúYou fucking posers. Three years ago, everybody was all into Ukrainian flags. What happened to that? Another cause tossed into the junk drawer with yesterday‚Äôs choke collar?‚Äù He called virtue signaling ‚Äúbody ornaments‚Äù and delivered one of his trademark zingers: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just crucifixes for liberals. Because every time I see one, I think, ‚ÄòJesus Christ.‚Äô‚Äù

Maher gave a nod to Ricky Gervais‚Äôs now-legendary roast of Hollywood‚Äôs award show activism during the 2020 Golden Globe awards, when he said,

Maher, of course, agreed with Gervais, adding, ‚ÄúCelebrities absolutely do have a right to speak out. I‚Äôm just saying: Don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs having the opposite effect of what you want.‚Äù

Maher then pointed to the 2024 election cycle, where ‚Äúevery big name in show business came out for Kamala Harris, from Oprah to Clooney to Beyonc√©, and she lost every swing state.‚Äù

Maher highlighted data showing that Taylor Swift‚Äôs political endorsement actually drove voters away. 

The problem, he argued, is that stars are the least relatable people in the country at a time when affordability dominates public concern, pointing out that ‚Äúcelebrities don‚Äôt strike people as relatable or in touch. What their activism mostly activates is eye rolls.‚Äù

Celebrities, I know it‚Äôs very important to you that you feel that you‚Äôre making a difference, and you are, you‚Äôre making independents vote Republican. pic.twitter.com/EozEfoF8OZ
‚Äî Bill Maher (@billmaher) January 31, 2026

Hollywood's fake activism has a short shelf life. Stars slap on pins and flags to look good, then ditch the cause when the spotlight moves on because their activism is more about making them look good than about the cause they‚Äôre promoting. Maher nailed it‚Äîthese celebs treat virtue like cheap jewelry, shiny for one night, trash the next. People are sick of it. 

Maher ended the tirade with a final swipe at celebrity activism. ‚ÄúDemocrats, it‚Äôs great you have all the big celebs, but people see them as an arm of the Democratic Party, which they already suspect for lacking common sense. I know celebrities mean well, and we thank them for having their heart in the right place.‚Äù

He added, ‚ÄúJust do you. Use your extraordinary talents for the noble cause of bringing relief from the problems that ribbons and pins can‚Äôt fix. I know it‚Äôs very important to you that you feel that you‚Äôre making a difference... so let me assure you, you are. You‚Äôre making independents vote Republican.‚Äù
news.author: Tyler Durden

news.title: Gary Bauer: The Laken Riley Act
news.text:
Thursday marked the one-year anniversary of the Laken Riley Act‚Äîthe first bill President Trump signed into law in his second term. The law is named after the Georgia nursing student who was brutally attacked and murdered in 2024 by an illegal alien from Venezuela, Jose Ibarra. This thug was allowed into our country by Joe Biden.

Laken Riley was just one of many American victims of the Left‚Äôs insane open border and sanctuary city policies. Those policies allow illegal foreign nationals to rob, rape, and murder American citizens. Jose Ibarra had multiple run-ins with law enforcement in New York and in Georgia, but he was released each time.

If our immigration laws had been enforced during the Biden/Harris years, Laken Riley would be alive today. If sanctuary cities cooperated with federal immigration police, Laken Riley would be alive today.

The Laken Riley Act requires illegal foreign nationals charged with violent crimes to be detained by federal immigration police‚Äîthe very thing that Democrats in Minnesota and other sanctuary jurisdictions refuse to do.

Since President Trump signed the Laken Riley Act into law on January 29, 2025, more than 21,000 illegal aliens have been arrested by federal authorities under this act. Think about that‚Äî21,000 in just one year!

If Kamala Harris had won the 2024 election, she would have vetoed the Laken Riley Act, and those 21,000 criminal foreign nationals would still be free and terrorizing innocent Americans.

As a reminder, nearly 75% of House and Senate Democrats opposed the Laken Riley Act. They voted ‚Äúno‚Äù on a commonsense measure to protect our daughters, sisters, and mothers from being raped and murdered by criminal illegal aliens who shouldn‚Äôt be here.

The Fanatical Mayor Frey

Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey addressed the U.S. Conference of Mayors in Washington, D.C., Thursday. On the one-year anniversary of the Laken Riley Act, Frey denounced the enforcement of federal immigration law in his city as ‚Äúan invasion of our democracy.‚Äù He urged other mayors to resist the Trump administration, or the ‚Äúinvasion‚Äù would come to their cities.

No, it won‚Äôt because many cities are cooperating with the administration. But what jumped out at me was his use of the word ‚Äúinvasion.‚Äù Well, let‚Äôs talk about invasions.

We don‚Äôt know how many illegal foreign nationals crossed our border during the Biden years‚Äî10 million, 12 million, 20 million. But there were also 2 million ‚Äúgotaways.‚Äù

Rather than surrendering at the border and being welcomed in by the Biden administration, these people paid more to avoid being caught. Why? There is every reason to assume they are among the worst of the worst.

This may be unprecedented in world history‚Äîmillions and millions of people crossing the border of a major world power. That is an invasion! And the Biden/Harris regime didn‚Äôt try to stop it‚Äîthey facilitated it.

Conservatives were condemned when we used the word ‚Äúinvasion‚Äù to describe the record daily violations of our southern border. We were accused of spreading ‚Äúconspiracy theories‚Äù and of being ‚Äúwhite supremacists.‚Äù

Democrats and their media allies insisted that every one of these ‚Äúmigrants‚Äù were future doctors or entrepreneurs we just couldn‚Äôt live without.

But when we send federal agents to enforce the laws of the United States to get gang members, drug dealers, child molesters, rapists, and murderers out of our country, that‚Äôs an ‚Äúinvasion.‚Äù

Minnesota Musings

Minnesota Senator Amy Klobuchar (D) announced Thursday that she is running for governor. She does not have to resign until she wins, meaning she can still serve in the Senate while campaigning for governor.

The day before, scandal-plagued Governor Tim Walz announced, ‚ÄúI will never run for an elected office again. Never again.‚Äù The timing of these announcements is curious.

Many insiders believe Klobuchar will likely win her race for governor, as she remains popular in the state. There is speculation that when she takes the oath as governor, she will appoint Walz to her Senate seat.

If there is any truth to this scheme, every decent citizen in Minnesota ought to be outraged.

By the way, I was reminded this week that the left-wing violence we‚Äôre seeing in Minneapolis right now is nothing new. The city hosted the 2008 Republican National Convention, which I attended.

Not only were there daily riots resulting in more than 800 arrests, but law enforcement agencies also conducted several preemptive raids prior to the convention and uncovered a plot by dozens of Marxist revolutionaries to disrupt and even bomb the convention. (Here and here.)

A Spanish Lesson

Spain is currently ruled by a coalition between the Socialist Party and the far-left Podemos Party. This left-wing coalition just announced that it is granting amnesty to 500,000 illegal aliens who walked into the country.

Spain‚Äôs populist conservative Vox Party strongly opposes the amnesty, but no one is voting on it. The radical left-wing coalition is going to ram it through by government edict, and they are not shy about their reasons. Podemos Secretary General Ione Belarra declared, ‚ÄúFascism is stopped with more rights.‚Äù

In other words, Spanish leftists are going to stop the ‚Äúfascist‚Äù Vox party by creating new voters.

Now, if you say that open borders Democrats are doing the same here‚Äîtrying to replace the electorate and create a new electorate‚Äîyou‚Äôre accused of spreading ‚Äúwhite supremacist conspiracy theories.‚Äù But the lesson from Spain is that it‚Äôs no conspiracy theory. It is exactly what the globalist Marxist Left is doing.

The Famine Lie

The Israel Defense Forces released a new report on casualties in the Hamas war. It found no evidence of a single death caused by famine. In fact, the Gaza Strip received 1,700,000 tons of food during the war.

In addition, 600,000 Palestinian children were vaccinated against polio during the war. There were also 60,000 live births recorded in Gaza last year, more than in 2022 before the war. How does all that happen during a ‚Äúfamine‚Äù and a ‚Äúgenocide‚Äù? (If only birth rates in the United States were as high as they are in Gaza!)

The few times the media tried to show us starving children, it was discovered that the children were seriously ill with diseases that were killing them before the war started.

If the Israelis are so ‚Äúevil‚Äù and ‚Äúcontrol everything,‚Äù they‚Äôre really not good at this ‚Äúgenocide‚Äù business.

Lemon Gets Squeezed

We were ecstatic to see the news that pretend ‚Äújournalist‚Äù Don Lemon was arrested Thursday night in Los Angeles for his role in the attack on Cities Church in St. Paul, Minnesota. Three other radical leftists were also arrested.

Lemon and his attorney claim that he is protected by the First Amendment as a reporter covering the event. All you have to do is look at the video. He wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúcovering‚Äù the event. He got into the pastor‚Äôs face and argued with him in the middle of the service.

If any conservative commentator‚ÄîLaura Ingraham, Sean Hannity, or Mark Levin‚Äîstormed a mosque with a group of committed Christians, disrupted the service, and got in the face of the imam, do you think anyone would defend that commentator as being protected by the First Amendment? Of course not.

What if one of the left‚Äôs sacred spaces was invaded by Christians? We don‚Äôt have to guess at the reaction. It already happened.

When pro-life activists, including elderly men and women, blocked the entrance of an abortion clinic in Washington, D.C., they were treated like mass murderers by the Biden/Harris regime. They were arrested, prosecuted, and jailed. Even when one pro-life activist was suffering from serious health issues, the judge showed no mercy.

Virtually no one knows about this incident, except for those of us in the pro-life movement. It happened. It was a disgusting violation of the First Amendment, but the media doesn‚Äôt care if the rights of pro-life Christians are violated.

Trump‚Äôs Pick

President Trump nominated Kevin Warsh to be the next chairman of the Federal Reserve. Warsh previously served on the Federal Reserve Board from 2006 to 2011.

But here‚Äôs the disturbing thing: Sen. Thom Tillis (R), who praised Warsh‚Äôs qualifications, said he won‚Äôt confirm any nominee to the Federal Reserve until the investigation of Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell is ended. Without Tillis‚Äôs vote, the Senate Banking Committee would be split 12 to 12, and nominations do not advance on tied votes.

There is a wide consensus in the business community that the Federal Reserve should be insulated from political pressure regarding interest rates. But Tillis and other senators aren‚Äôt just saying the Federal Reserve should be independent.

They‚Äôre really saying there can‚Äôt be any oversight of the Federal Reserve. No investigations to see if fraud has been committed or if Federal Reserve employees violated the laws of the United States.

Once again, we see the establishment wing of the Republican Party siding with Democrats to thwart Trump‚Äôs agenda.

Summit Ministries

Young Americans are veering left at an alarming rate. They are increasingly embracing socialism. Few are proud to live in America. And even fewer have a biblical worldview. That‚Äôs where Summit Ministries comes in. 

Students hear from respected experts and learn conversational techniques to articulate the truth. After two weeks at Summit, 94% report a better understanding of the Christian worldview and feel better prepared to defend their faith.

If you have a child or grandchild in high school or college, I highly recommend Summit Ministries! Their Student Conferences are filling up fast, so please take a few minutes right now to reserve a seat for a young adult you love.

Use code AMERICANVALUES26 to get a $250 discount.

Thanks to President Trump‚Äôs policies, tax refunds will be $1,000 larger this year. That‚Äôs real help for Americans struggling with the affordability crisis created by the inflationary policies of Joe Biden and congressional Democrats. 

The Trump administration repealed a Biden-era rule forcing 60,000 retail pharmacies to sell abortion-inducing pills to ‚Äúpregnant persons‚Äù if the pharmacies did any business with any federally funded program, including Medicare and Medicaid. The Trump administration said the Biden rule violated laws against federal funding of abortion and also clarified that ‚Äúonly women and girls can be pregnant.‚Äù 

Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, Steak N‚Äô Shake, and Turning Point USA announced they will match the $1,000 federal contribution for their employees who set up Trump Accounts for their children. Hopefully other businesses will follow their example. 

Thanks to President Trump‚Äôs policies, U.S. steel companies outproduced their Japanese competitors for the first time in 25 years.

news.title: Will Bad Bunny call out ICE at the Super Bowl?
news.text:
Fresh off his historic Album of the Year win at the 2026 Grammys for DeB√ç TiRAR M√°S FOToS, Bad Bunny is set to headline the Super Bowl LX halftime show on Feb. 8 ‚Äî a performance poised to become yet another culture-shifting moment on the world's biggest stage. At the Grammys, the Puerto Rican superstar didn't shy away from politics, directly calling out U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement with a pointed "ICE out" during his acceptance speech for M√∫sica Urbana Album. Now, as he prepares for one of the most-watched performances in the world, the question remains: Will Bad Bunny bring that same unapologetic message to the Super Bowl?Bad Bunny's history of speaking out against ICEIf Benito does take on ICE at the Super Bowl, it wouldn‚Äôt be the first time. In a September 2025 interview with i-D magazine, he said concerns over potential ICE raids and the safety of his Latino and Puerto Rican fans were a key reason he excluded the United States from his 2025‚Äì2026 DeB√ç TiRAR M√°S FOToS World Tour. 

 Bad Bunny slams ICE during Grammys speech

"People from the U.S. could come here to see the show. Latinos and Puerto Ricans of the United States could also travel here, or to any part of the world," he said. "But there was the issue that ‚Ä¶ ICE could be outside (my concert venue). And it‚Äôs something that we were talking about and very concerned about."Instead, the artist staged a historic 31-date residency in Puerto Rico ‚Äî one intentionally designed to prioritize local fans, keep ticket prices accessible, and inject more than $400 million into the island's economy. The decision underscored not only his connection to the island but also his ongoing concern for the communities most affected by immigration enforcement.That awareness surfaced again during the Grammys telecast, when host Trevor Noah joked, "If things keep getting worse in America, can I come live with you in Puerto Rico?" Bad Bunny gently corrected him: "Puerto Rico is part of America." The moment landed lightly, but its implications were a reminder of Puerto Rico's complicated political status and the way Latinx communities are often treated as both central to and peripheral within American life. His criticism of ICE has been consistent. Last June, Bad Bunny shared a video on his Instagram Story condemning federal agents operating in Puerto Rico, urging them to stop harassing people who were simply trying to work. With ICE operations intensifying under the Trump administration, his past comments suggest this activism is not a fleeting statement but a throughline in his career. And as a Puerto Rican artist whose music openly celebrates the island, it wouldn‚Äôt be surprising if the Super Bowl stage became yet another place where he chooses to make that message heard.Has Bad Bunny ever criticized President Trump?While Bad Bunny has rarely named Donald Trump outright, his criticism of the former president ‚Äî and the policies of his administration ‚Äî has been clear. In 2024, the artist endorsed Kamala Harris for U.S. president, citing frustration with the Trump administration‚Äôs handling of Hurricane Maria and its devastating impact on Puerto Rico. He made the public endorsement in the wake of comedian Tony Hinchcliffe‚Äôs racist remarks about Puerto Rico at a Trump rally at Madison Square Garden, where the island was referred to as a "floating island of garbage."His commentary has also surfaced through his music. On this past Fourth of July, Bad Bunny released the music video for "NUEVAYoL," a salsa tribute to the Puerto Rican diaspora in New York. 

 window.videoEmbeds = window.videoEmbeds || [];
 window.videoEmbeds.push({
 elemId: 'video-container-01KGFF0XVHQ2APXP79YDDZ8MQK',
 data: {"slug":"KU5V5WZVcVE","url":"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=KU5V5WZVcVE","start_time":""},
 videoPlayerType: 'in-content'

The visual features the singer perched atop the Statue of Liberty, who wears a Puerto Rican flag across her forehead like a bandanna. In the final moments, a Trump-like voice plays over a radio broadcast, issuing an imagined apology to immigrants. "This country is nothing without the immigrants," the voice says, naming Mexicans, Dominicans, Puerto Ricans, Colombians, Venezuelans, and Cubans in an unmistakable rebuke of Trump-era immigration rhetoric.Tensions escalated further after the NFL announced Bad Bunny as the Super Bowl LX halftime performer. U.S. Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem publicly criticized the decision, saying ICE agents would be "all over" the Super Bowl and suggesting the event should be reserved for "law-abiding Americans who love this country."The following night, Bad Bunny addressed the backlash during his Saturday Night Live monologue. Speaking first in English, then in Spanish, he framed the moment as a collective victory for Latino communities in the United States, emphasizing their labor and cultural impact. "Our footprints and our contribution in this country," he said, "no one will ever be able to take that away or erase it." He closed with a pointed aside in English: "And if you didn‚Äôt understand what I just said, you have four months to learn."Trump himself responded dismissively when asked about Bad Bunny in October, telling NewsMax he had "never heard of him" and questioning why the NFL selected him as the halftime performer. Just last month, he told the New York Post that he would not attend Super Bowl LX, citing Bad Bunny and opening act Green Day as reasons. "I'm anti-them," Trump said, "I think it's a terrible choice. All it does is sow hatred. Terrible."We'll have to wait until Super Bowl Sunday to see if Benito responds. So, will Bad Bunny mention ICE or Trump at the Super Bowl?Whether or not Bad Bunny directly addresses politics at Super Bowl LX, the act of bringing Puerto Rican culture and its history to the world's biggest stage is itself a statement. For Bad Bunny, music and identity have always been inseparable, and this halftime show will surely be no exception.
news.summary: Bad Bunny has long criticized U.S. immigration policy and Trump-era politics. Will he speak out at Super Bowl LX?
news.author: Crystal Bell

news.title: Black Coaches Shut Out Of Hiring Cycle And Enraged Media Will Make Goodell Answer For It As A Result
news.text: SAN FRANCISCO ‚Äì NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell will have his annual state of the league press conference Monday, and after the final job of the latest head coach hiring cycle was filled over the weekend, we already know what a significant number of questions from the 100 or so invited reporters will be: Why weren't any black head coach hired? This is not a guess. It's a virtual certainty the race of the coaches hired will dominate this press conference. Sunday afternoon on X already showed ample evidence of reporters of all shades voicing their distaste for the hiring of nine white men and one man of Lebanese descent, while black men were somehow unfairly excluded. Reporter Uses Racist ‚ÄòGood Ol‚Äô Boys' Trope At least one of those reporters even gave a preview to the coming anger by sharing a theory (without evidence) that the hiring of white coaches came as a result of a "good ol' boy club" ‚Äì a racist trope as unfair as claiming black coaches are all DEI hires. Nine of the 10 teams that replaced coaches this cycle hired white men. Robert Saleh, whose parents emigrated from Lebanon, was the lone non-white coach hired this cycle when he accepted the job with the Tennessee Titans. And as two of the candidates that either lost their job (Raheem Morris in Atlanta) or stepped down (Mike Tomlin in Pittsburgh) are black, that means there will be two fewer black head coaches in the NFL in 2026 than there were in 2025. There will be three black NFL head coaches in 2026. Those are Todd Bowles in Tampa Bay, Aaron Glenn in New York and DeMeco Ryans in Houston. And during Monday's press conference, it will seem from the questioning as if the net loss is clearly Goodell's fault. And he must answer for it. NFL Can't Tell Teams Who To Hire But what just happened across the league is not Goodell's doing. And it's not the NFL's doing. The NFL doesn't run head coach searches. Or coordinator searches. Or assistant coach searches. The league doesn't make the final calls on those hires. Multiple NFL sources made the point to OutKick in recent weeks that while the NFL hopes for the best outcome to all job searches, and that includes "the hiring of outstanding diverse candidates," the league cannot mandate who teams hire. That's done at the club level by owners who pick the coach they're probably going to fire within a four- or five-year span if recent history is any measure ‚Äì because teams generally fail spectacularly at this hiring coach thing. This is who the individual clubs hired this cycle: Left Leaning Blank, Rooney Racists? There is no way to guarantee some team owners don't have some bias or perhaps even prejudices in their hearts. But it is a leap to believe, for example, that ‚Ä¶ The Falcons, owned by Kamala Harris supporter and President Trump dissenter Arthur Blank, fired a black coach in Morris and hired a white coach because a two-time coach of the year named Stefanski is part of some good ol' boy club. Blank, by the way, hired Ian Cunningham as his new general manager. Cunningham is black. The Steelers, owned by Art Rooney II, were going to keep Tomlin against considerable public outcry in Western Pennsylvania. So did the family who authored the NFL's Rooney Rule, the family that served Barack Obama in an ambassador role to Ireland, make a decision to hire a past Super Bowl winner with strong ties to Aaron Rodgers because they're racists? It's hard to believe the Bills, who wanted to keep some sense of continuity for quarterback Josh Allen, hired Brady merely because he's white. Because maybe, just maybe, he was a hot prospect throughout the league and was the Bills offensive coordinator that helped Allen win the MVP in 2024. Multiple White Candidates Earned Jobs It's hard to believe Kubiak wasn't attractive to the Raiders based on the fact he runs an offense in Seattle that has Sam Darnold starting at quarterback in Super Bowl LX. Kubiak has Darnold starting the Super Bowl is a phrase that would've gotten him the keys to New York City in 2018-2020. John Harbaugh to the Giants? What black, brown, orange or green coach should be hired ahead of the best available coach in the cycle? Jesse Minter replaced Harbaugh in Baltimore. And the Ravens beat out the Falcons, Browns, Raiders, Dolphins, Steelers, and Titans who also had interest in Minter. So was this a good ol' boy hire? Because that would mean the club is massive. LaFleur was hired by the Cardinals. Even the hapless Cardinals recognized that LaFleur's older brother is a successful head coach in Green Bay, and the younger brother is the latest offensive coordinator to emerge from a Sean McVay coaching tree that also produced Jaguars coach Liam Coen, Vikings coach Kevin O'Connell, and the older LaFleur. Goodell Will Virtue Signal The amazing thing about these facts is that Goodell will almost definitely virtue signal that the NFL wants more diverse (black) candidates even though it's not within the league's reach to guarantee that. In that regard, Goodell will look as woke as media members demanding more black coaches be hired without addressing every situation individually to outline where an actual wrong was done.

news.title: Trump Torches Grammys, Threatens to Sue ‚ÄòTalentless Dope‚Äô Host Trevor Noah Over Epstein Comments
news.text:
President Trump may have had the misfortune of being one of the few people taking in the Grammy Awards last night, and frankly, he didn't like what he saw. He posted his thoughts in a late-night screed on Truth Social.

"The Grammy Awards are the WORST, virtually unwatchable!" he wrote. "CBS is lucky not to have this garbage litter their airwaves any longer."

The only thing one might quibble with in that assessment is the word "virtually." The Grammy Awards, like any vanity project for the entertainment elite, are flat-out always unwatchable. Unbearable even.

The President then took aim at host Trevor Noah, the failed former host of the "Daily Show," over what he described as a "defamatory" joke at his expense involving Jeffrey Epstein. In fact, he strongly hinted that Noah could expect a George "Slopadopolus"-level lawsuit on the horizon.

"The host, Trevor Noah, whoever he may be, is almost as bad as Jimmy Kimmel at the Low Ratings Academy Awards," Trump said. 

"I can‚Äôt speak for Bill, but I have never been to Epstein Island, nor anywhere close, and until tonight‚Äôs false and defamatory statement, have never been accused of being there, not even by the Fake News Media," he continued, referencing the host's joke. "Noah, a total loser, better get his facts straight, and get them straight fast."

"It looks like I‚Äôll be sending my lawyers to sue this poor, pathetic, talentless, dope of an M.C., and suing him for plenty$. Ask Little George Slopadopolus and others how that all worked out. Also, ask CBS!" added Trump. "Get ready, Noah, I‚Äôm going to have some fun with you!

READ MORE: Failed ‚ÄòDaily Show‚Äô Host Faces Backlash After Stand-Up Bit Mocking Kirk‚Äôs Assassination

Noah and the CBS network (the Grammys move to Disney/ABC in 2027) might want to start prepping. Trump's threats against defamation do not typically ring hollow. And he has a track record of winning.

ABC News and Slopadopolus were forced to settle a defamation lawsuit brought by the President the previous December after the "This Week" co-host falsely accused him of rape. The network agreed to pay $15 million in damages and apologized. He won a $16 million payout from CBS for their deceptive interview with Kamala Harris. He recently filed a $10 billion lawsuit against the BBC for deceptively editing his remarks on January 6th.

He's not one to be trifled with. What did Noah do that set him off? Lumped him into the same category as former President Bill Clinton when it comes to Epstein's island.

Following the announcement that Billie Eilish had won for Song of the Year, Noah joked, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a Grammy that every artist wants ‚Äî almost as much as Trump wants Greenland."

‚ÄúWhich makes sense because, since Epstein‚Äôs gone, he needs a new island to hang out with Bill Clinton," he added. "I told you, it‚Äôs my last year! What are you going to do about it?‚Äù

Aside from the fact that Noah is desperately trying to copy an actual comedian in Ricky Gervais with the shtick, it looks like the President has already decided exactly what he's going to do about it.

Trev, buddy, Gervais already did the 'it's my last year' routine and nailed it. Meaning much of your career has been spent trying to be a carbon copy of more accomplished comedians like him and Jon Stewart.

Noah recently raised the ire of conservatives over a stand-up bit in which he joked about what he found to be humorous about the Charlie Kirk assassination.

"I'm sure there's something funny about it. The guy was shot while defending guns. I'm not even writing that as a joke, as a human, you have to admit that is an incongruous, funny thing that happens," he said.

Desperately seeking attention by playing Barney Rubble to Stewart's Fred Flintstone, driving the "Daily Show" ratings into the toilet, then not having enough material to come up with anything original as host of the Grammys, all while setting yourself up for a career-ending lawsuit‚ÄîNow that's funny.

Editor‚Äôs Note: Do you enjoy RedState‚Äôs conservative reporting that takes on the radical left and woke media? Support our work so that we can continue to bring you the truth.

Join RedState VIP and use the promo code FIGHT to get 60% off your VIP membership!
news.author: Rusty Weiss

news.title: Donald Trump threatens to sue comedian Trevor Noah over Grammys Epstein joke
news.text:
President Donald Trump has threatened to sue Grammys host Trevor Noah after a joke he made about Jeffrey Epstein on stage.

The US President blasted the comedian as a ‚Äútotal loser‚Äù, adding: ‚ÄúIt looks like I‚Äôll be sending my lawyers to sue this poor, pathetic, talentless, dope of an M.C., and suing him for plenty$.‚Äù

Mr Trump criticised Noah‚Äôs joke, made after the song of the year gong was handed out.

Writing on Truth Social, in a post strewn with uppercase words, Mr Trump: ‚ÄúNoah said, INCORRECTLY about me, that Donald Trump and Bill Clinton spent time on Epstein Island. WRONG!!!

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt speak for Bill, but I have never been to Epstein Island, nor anywhere close, and until tonight‚Äôs false and defamatory statement, have never been accused of being there, not even by the Fake News Media.

‚ÄúNoah, a total loser, better get his facts straight, and get them straight fast.‚Äù

He added: ‚ÄúGet ready Noah, I‚Äôm going to have some fun with you!‚Äù

Mr Trump also blasted the ceremony saying: ‚ÄúThe Grammy Awards are the WORST, virtually unwatchable! CBS is lucky not to have this garbage litter their airwaves any longer.‚Äù

This is an apparent reference to Disney taking over the broadcast rights for the award ceremony starting next year.

Mr Trump is famously litigious and has taken legal action against the BBC over the editing of a Panorama programme.

He has also engaged in legal action with the New York Times, Associated Press and the Wall Street Journal.

Last July, US media giant Paramount, which owns CBS, agreed to pay Mr Trump 16 million dollars (¬£13.5 million) to settle a lawsuit over a 2024 CBS interview with Kamala Harris, the former vice-president and 2024 Democratic presidential nominee.

Noah, 41, is a South African-born comedian and TV personality who hosted The Daily Show on Comedy Central in the US for seven years.
news.summary: He also blasted the ceremony as ‚Äòunwatchable‚Äô.
news.author: Laura Harding

news.title: The voters who could decide Texas‚Äô top races
news.text:
What the voters campaigns are chasing say matters in this year‚Äôs election.

On the border

Laredo native Alex M√©ndez‚Äôs voting record zigzags between parties, with years of sitting out elections.

The 50-year-old tech professional voted Republican in 2016, skipped 2020 and voted Democratic in 2024, rarely participating in midterms.

He blames the Democratic Party‚Äôs decision to switch Joe Biden with Kamala Harris for alienating voters and helping Donald Trump return to office.

‚ÄúThat was a big, big mistake,‚Äù he said.

This year, M√©ndez said anger over immigration enforcement will drive him to vote in both the primary and general election for candidates who support an end to the immigrant-targeting raids on Texans‚Äô homes.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what‚Äôs really bothering me right now, all the ICE actions,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSeparating families, deporting people, going into people‚Äôs homes.‚Äù

The suburbs

Coppell entrepreneur Pam Varnell, 63, has voted Republican in every election since turning 18 years old. 

Varnell is upset by what she sees as overspending on social programs, fraud in public benefits and tax cuts that fail to meaningfully lower costs for homeowners and small businesses.

‚ÄúYou can have empathy and provide support but also demand that the government do its job,‚Äù she said.

Much of her irritation is aimed at local government but she‚Äôs tired of the stalemates caused by extremes at all levels, particularly in Washington.

‚ÄúThere are a lot of common sense things out there that could be voted on, but nobody wants to take the hit,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúEverybody wants the win.‚Äù

Rural Texas

In the tiny town of Axtell, northeast of Waco, Jermane Burks teaches English at a public high school and worries the state is failing to support rural schools.

Like many in both parties in rural Texas, Burks is wary that private school vouchers will undercut schools and local jobs. 

Though he doesn‚Äôt claim a party, the 44-year-old said his voting leans Democratic, and this year he‚Äôs focused less on labels than on where candidates stand.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to make sure I do my best due diligence,‚Äù he said. 

He said Republican policies and messages have deepened tensions between parents and teachers and weakened trust in public education.

‚ÄúWhat they‚Äôre saying out loud is not what‚Äôs happening in classrooms,‚Äù he said.

Republican country

Bill Finstad, 56, is a GOP precinct chair in North Richland Hills, referred to by its mayor as ‚Äúthe largest conservative city in Tarrant County.‚Äù 

Finstad said he was inspired to take on the partisan role last year out of frustration with what he views as unresponsive elected officials and growing bureaucracy.

‚ÄúThe excessive and clearly avoidable bureaucracy‚Ä¶ prompted me to get more involved,‚Äù Finstad said.

On the ground, he said many voters are worried about housing costs, the power grid and taxes, and they aren‚Äôt seeing enough action.

They also are increasingly tired of political division, he said.

‚ÄúPeople are hungry for genuine leadership,‚Äù he said.

Democratic country

As a freshly minted Democratic precinct chair in Southeast Texas, Amber Delaune is marking little victories. 

A 34-year-old bookkeeper and married mother of a 4-year-old, Delaune cited volunteer efforts in her rural Hardin County precinct near Beaumont. 

That outreach has brought about 100 voters into the party in a district that voted nearly 90% Republican in the last election.

She said concerns about public education, property taxes, child care, health care and limited social services motivating voters looking for change.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve had 30 years to make this better. And it‚Äôs worse,‚Äù she said of Texas Republicans. ‚ÄúIf your big plan is to lower property taxes, how are you going to fund our schools?‚Äù
news.author: Karen Brooks Harper

news.title: No 'Republican is safe right now': How MAGA lost a district Trump carried by 17 points
news.text:
In September 2024, Texas Rep. Ram√≥n Romero was at a fundraiser in Fort Worth for Kamala Harris when he met a young labor leader named Taylor Rehmet.

The Air Force veteran and union machinist told Romero he was mulling a run for public office. A lot of people think about running, Romero recounted telling him, but he offered to help should Rehmet actually file. 

The two stayed in touch, and Rehmet decided last summer to run in a special election for a ruby red Texas Senate district in Tarrant County that no Democrat had represented in nearly half a century and that President Donald Trump won by more than 17 points in 2024. When Romero mobilized to help Rehmet court Latino voters ‚Äî many of them from the same Fort Worth neighborhoods he represents in the House ‚Äî he saw a serious first-time candidate meeting power brokers, talking to voters on front porches and running a long-shot bid like he could win it. 

On Saturday, Rehmet did win it, in part thanks to a spike in support from the Latino vote. 

He defeated conservative activist Leigh Wambsganss ‚Äî whose campaign far outspent Rehmet ‚Äî by a decisive 14-point margin in a stunner that reverberated from Texas to Mar-a-Lago, refreshing Democrats‚Äô dreams of a blue Texas and rattling Republicans as they brace for more aftershocks in November. 

Rehmet‚Äôs upset victory, according to interviews Sunday with half a dozen people who supported or worked on his campaign, is explained by a variety of factors, including the combination of Latino and suburban backlash to once-fringe conservative policies that have taken root in Tarrant County and Washington; a MAGA opponent who drove some of those policies and embraced them on the campaign trail; and a message from Rehmet, centered on his union background, that won over working-class voters, independents and even some moderate Republicans. 

Instrumental to Rehmet‚Äôs victory was the backing he received from Hispanics, who account for slightly more than one in five eligible voters in the district. One analyst found that Rehmet outperformed Harris, the 2024 Democratic presidential nominee, by more than 50 points in some of the largely Hispanic areas of Fort Worth. The remarkable shifts occurred as those voters witnessed immigration agents in recent weeks kill two Americans while trying to carry out the president‚Äôs promised mass deportations. And those same voters, some observers noted, believed Trump would help their financial standing more than what he has delivered in his first year in office. 

Up against Rehmet was a ferocious campaign fueled by some of the GOP‚Äôs biggest heavyweights ‚Äî Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and Trump among them. They backed Wambsganss, who‚Äôs set to get a rematch against Rehmet in November for a four-year term, as Rehmet‚Äôs victory was only to complete the remaining 11 months in a term Republican Kelly Hancock left to become Texas‚Äô acting comptroller.

‚ÄúHe is a hard worker. People think that you can just win elections. You‚Äôre gonna have to really work it, and he did,‚Äù Romero, who block-walked for Rehmet, said in an interview Sunday. ‚ÄúI had more Republicans ‚Äî people calling me saying, ‚ÄòI voted for Rehmet.‚Äô ‚ÄòI voted for Rehmet.‚Äô ‚ÄòHey, I just want you to know ‚Äî I voted for Rehmet.‚Äô‚Äù

To be sure, the election was unique. It was held on a Saturday in January, with no other candidates on the ballot, following a cold snap that affected campaigning and early voting. The singularity limits what can be gleaned from Rehmet‚Äôs stunning upset. But as the blame game among Republicans grew louder on Sunday, it also became clear that the 32-point swing for Democrats could not be simply dismissed as irrelevant. 

Still, some Democrats counseled restraint in interpreting the results. 

‚ÄúI don't think that Democrats should think that just because Taylor won last night, that it‚Äôs New York City time. It's not New York City time. It's not Vermont time. It's not LA time,‚Äù said U.S. Rep. Marc Veasey, a Fort Worth Democrat, noting that Texas is far from becoming one of the country‚Äôs liberal bastions. ‚ÄúIf you are a candidate running in a tough race in a place like Texas, it does not mean that you can start California dreaming.‚Äù

By numerous indications, the election should have been a sleepy one. Aside from Trump‚Äôs margin in 2024, the district has been reliably red: Per one analysis, Republicans have carried it by an average of nearly 19 points in 44 state and federal contests since 2018. 

The first indication that the race would be a live one arrived in November, when Rehmet finished three points shy of winning the seat outright. 

In both rounds, but especially in the runoff, Texas GOP leaders went to bat for Wambsganss, tapping into their own funds, block-walking the district and ringing alarms about the race, saying they needed to keep the seat red and away from a radical Democrat. 

In all, Wambsganss‚Äô campaign reported raising $2.6 million, almost two-thirds ‚Äî $1.6 million ‚Äî of which came from three of the most powerful and loaded groups in Texas GOP politics. Texans United for a Conservative Majority, started by right-wing West Texas oil billionaires Tim Dunn and Farris Wilks, gave her campaign nearly $603,000 ‚Äî more than Rehmet‚Äôs entire campaign haul of some $570,000.

The Texas Senate Leadership Fund, a PAC started by Patrick, who oversees the state Senate, added $463,250. And the influential tort reform group Texans For Lawsuit Reform PAC added $550,000.

Rehmet‚Äôs campaign knew it simply could not raise the same amount of money, his campaign strategist Jake Davis said in an interview Sunday. 

But the camp was also not interested in a strategy that involved matching Wambsganss dollar for dollar, Davis said. Knowing they would be outgunned on the advertising airwaves, Davis instead sought out to assemble a staff of Texans from across the state, based them in Tarrant County and identified a north star of knocking on 40,000 doors. 

Every week, they worked backward from that target ‚Äî spending time with people in their living rooms, kitchens and driveways. The staff received training on active listening, Davis said. If a voter had a question the volunteer did not have an answer for, Rehmet‚Äôs team would run it down ‚Äî sometimes calling the candidate himself in front of the voter. 

‚ÄúWe had to stay relentlessly disciplined,‚Äù Davis said. ‚ÄúEvery single dollar, every hour, every volunteer shift, had to have a purpose. There were so many un-sexy decisions that we had to make.‚Äù

Of course, the campaign received help, like from Romero ‚Äî as well as from Beto O‚ÄôRourke, the Democratic darling who shattered fundraising goals and expectations in 2018 when he almost unseated U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz. 

O‚ÄôRourke‚Äôs political group, Powered by People, helped register people to vote in the district, stayed in touch with them to encourage them to vote and called and texted 30,000 voters eligible to vote by mail. In an interview Sunday, the former El Paso congressman credited Rehmet‚Äôs campaign for the victory ‚Äî and struck an optimistic tone for Democrats in November. 

‚ÄúI don't think any Republican is safe right now,‚Äù O‚ÄôRourke said. ‚ÄúI think the people of Texas have absolutely had it and are looking for change.‚Äù

Bo French, until recently the Tarrant County GOP chair, blamed poor turnout among Republican voters.

‚ÄúI see a lot of Republicans blaming everyone from the Governor to the county party,‚Äù French wrote on social media. ‚ÄúRepublicans need to wake up. When you stay home during local elections and special elections, Democrats win. You can't blame others for your failure to vote.‚Äù

Some party superiors see a serious threat. In an early Sunday social media post, Patrick vowed to keep fighting and take the seat back in November.

‚ÄúLow turnout special elections are always unpredictable,‚Äù Patrick wrote. ‚ÄúThe results from SD 9 are a wake-up call for Republicans across Texas. Our voters cannot take anything for granted.‚Äù

Trump, for his part, distanced himself from the loss, spinning heads in the process after he had posted three different get-out-the-vote messages in the 48 hours leading up to the election. 

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not involved in that,‚Äù Trump told reporters at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a local Texas race.‚Äù

As political observers tried to make sense of the upset, a range of theories emerged to explain what still remained inexplicable to many as the dust settled: It was a referendum on Trump, it was a response to socially conservative policies, it was a response to the hard-right turn of local GOP leaders, it was a poorly run GOP campaign, and onward.

John Huffman, the Republican former Southlake mayor who finished a distant third in the November election, chalked it up to ‚Äúfailed opportunities to unify.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere was no outreach to the 19,000 voters who supported our campaign in November,‚Äù Huffman wrote on social media. ‚ÄúNor did Leigh's campaign reach out to me until days before early voting began, leaving no time to unify Republicans or broaden the coalition. When she and I finally did meet, she ended the conversation almost as soon as it started.‚Äù

On paper, Wambsganss‚Äô envious conservative bona fides were unmatched by many GOP candidates seeking office in Texas. 

She is the chief communications officer for Patriot Mobile, a cellphone company that has helped back the Christian conservative school board candidates who overhauled libraries, curricula and raised hell in board meetings across the state about what children are taught.

She had the backing of party state leaders and the district‚Äôs former state senator.

‚ÄúThey could have built her in their garage,‚Äù veteran Texas Democratic operative Matt Angle said. ‚ÄúTaylor Rehmet is just an absolute reflection of that district. Leigh Wambsganss is an absolute reflection of national MAGA. The voters decided which one they like, and it wasn't a close call.‚Äù

Still, political observers reiterated the uniqueness of the election and the challenges of trying to draw conclusions from an election that only drew a sliver of registered voters. 

Jason Villalba, a former Republican state representative who now leads the Texas Hispanic Policy Foundation, predicted Latinos ‚Äî ‚Äúthe most important swing vote in the country,‚Äù he said ‚Äî will continue to vote in surprising ways in coming elections. He cautioned that such voting trends ‚Äúin today‚Äôs climate move at light speed.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don't think you can take what happened last night and say, that's gonna hold into November, and these numbers are now static and nothing‚Äôs going to change,‚Äù Villalba said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs early. This was a strong indicator that Hispanics are moving back toward Democrats.‚Äù

This article first appeared on The Texas Tribune.
news.summary:
In September 2024, Texas Rep. Ram√≥n Romero was at a fundraiser in Fort Worth for Kamala Harris when he met a young labor leader named Taylor Rehmet.

The Air Force veteran and union machinist told Romero he was mulling a run for public office. A lot of people think about running, Romero recounted telling him, but he offered to help should Rehmet actually file. 

The two stayed in touch, and Rehmet decided last summer to run in a special election for a ruby red Texas Senate district in Tarrant County that no Democrat had represented in nearly half a century and that President Donald Trump won by more than 17 points in 2024. When Romero mobilized to help Rehmet court Latino voters ‚Äî many of them from the same Fort Worth neighborhoods he represents in the House ‚Äî he saw a serious first-time candidate meeting power brokers, talking to voters on front porches and running a long-shot bid like he could win it. 

On Saturday, Rehmet did win it, in part thanks to a spike in support from the Latino vote.

news.title: Gaga slammed over concert rant
news.text:
‚ÄúI want to take a second to talk about something that is extremely important to me, something important to people all over the world, and especially in America right now,‚Äù the 39-year-old singer said in the middle of her Mayhem Ball concert on Thursday.

‚ÄúIn a couple of days, I‚Äôm going to be heading home, and my heart is aching thinking about the people, the children, the families all over America who are being mercilessly targeted by ICE. I‚Äôm thinking about all of their pain and how their lives are being destroyed right in front of us.‚Äù

The law enforcement agency has been under scrutiny for the last few weeks after two people were shot and killed by ICE agents in separate incidents in Minneapolis this month.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm also thinking about Minnesota and everyone back at home who is living in so much fear and searching for answers on what we all should do,‚Äù the Oscar winner continued. ‚ÄúWhen entire communities lose their sense of safety and belonging, it breaks something in all of us. I hope that you‚Äôll all stand with us tonight. I know we‚Äôre not in America right now, but we are with our community, and we love you.‚Äù

The singer went on to dedicate her song Come to Mama to ‚Äúeveryone who is suffering, to everyone who is feeling alone and helpless, anyone who‚Äôs lost a loved one, and is having a difficult time, an impossible time, seeing when the end will be near.‚Äù

She added, ‚ÄúWe need to get back to a place of safety and peace and accountability. Good people shouldn‚Äôt have to fight so hard and risk their life for wellbeing and respect. And I hope our leaders are listening, I hope you are listening to us, asking you to change the course of action swiftly, and have mercy on everyone in our country. And in a time where it doesn‚Äôt feel like it‚Äôs easy to have hope, it is my community and my friends, my family that hold me up. So, I would like to sing a song that does have some hope in it, to try to give us a little bit tonight.‚Äù

While her audience wholeheartedly applauded her commentary, reaction was mixed on social media.

‚ÄúCould not care less,‚Äù one person wrote under a video posted to X of her comments.

‚ÄúShe is such a loser,‚Äù a second person wrote, with a third adding, ‚ÄúGaga is an anti-American psycho.‚Äù

A fourth said, ‚ÄúIf I came to Lady Gaga‚Äôs concert and heard her spew politics, I would yell out, ‚ÄòI came for a concert, not a political rally.‚Äô Then, demand my money back.‚Äù

‚ÄúStay you‚Äôre a** there you are not welcomed in our United States. Not wanted,‚Äù another wrote.

The singer had plenty of support on X as well.

‚ÄúI love her so much,‚Äù one fan said, while another admitted they ‚Äúcried my eyes out‚Äù listening to her speech.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so happy my favourite is someone I never have to worry about being on the wrong side of history,‚Äù a third added.

A fourth said, ‚ÄúWell said. Powerful words.‚Äù

Gaga has been outspoken about her political beliefs in the past. 

She endorsed former Vice President Kamala Harris in 2024 and told Elle UK after the election she had ‚Äúprayed‚Äù for President Donald Trump to lose. She is also a vocal advocate for the LGBTQ community. 

This story originally appeared on Fox News and is republished here with permission.
news.summary: Grammy winner Lady Gaga is facing backlash on social media after pausing her latest concert to slam the US government and ICE.

news.title: Bad Bunny wins top Grammy prize in a first for a Spanish-language album
news.text:
LOS ANGELES, (Reuters) ‚Äì Bad Bunny, the Latino rap star whose forthcoming Super Bowl gig has ignited a culture wars controversy, won the top Grammy prize yesterday, a first for a Spanish-language album, with ‚ÄúDeb√≠ Tirar M√°s Fotos,‚Äù a celebration of his Puerto Rican roots.

The 31-year-old performer-producer edged out fellow megastars Kendrick Lamar and Lady Gaga in what amounted to a three-way race to clinch his first album-of-the-year Grammy, considered the pinnacle of the music industry‚Äôs highest honors.

‚ÄúI want to dedicate this award to all the people who had to leave their homeland, their country to follow their dreams,‚Äù the Puerto Rican artist said in his acceptance speech, tapping into expressions of solidarity for immigrants evident throughout the show.

‚ÄúDeb√≠ Tirar M√°s Fotos,‚Äù a musical tribute to Bad Bunny‚Äôs Caribbean island homeland, marked his sixth studio set and was heavily favored after winning the Latin Grammys‚Äô album of the year award in November.

RECOGNITION OF BAD BUNNY CARRIES POLITICAL OVERTONES

Grammy recognition of Bad Bunny, born Benito Antonio Martinez Ocasio, carried strong political overtones given his outspoken criticism of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement sweeps ordered by U.S. President Donald Trump in cities across the country.The singer-producer skipped the continental United States on his recent concert tour, saying he feared federal immigration agents would show up to arrest his fans.

The Grammy accolades also burnished his reputation ahead of a wider introduction to a mainstream English-speaking U.S. audience next Sunday when he is due to headline the National Football League‚Äôs Super Bowl halftime show.

His selection for one of the marquee live sports and entertainment events on U.S. television has rankled some traditionalists, including Trump, who called it ‚Äúabsolutely ridiculous‚Äù and said he had never heard of Bad Bunny.

Bad Bunny openly supported Trump‚Äôs Democratic opponent Kamala Harris in the 2024 presidential race.

‚ÄúICE out,‚Äù he declared from the stage as he accepted the award for best Latin urban music album for ‚ÄúDeb√≠ Tirar M√°s Fotos,‚Äù one of five awards he received.

Opposition to Trump‚Äôs deportation drive emerged as a recurring theme throughout the three-hour-plus live Grammy telecast, in which many attendees, including Justin Bieber, were seen sporting ‚ÄúICE Out‚Äù buttons.

BEST NEW ARTIST OLIVIA DEAN

Accepting her award as best new artist, British soul-pop singer Olivia Dean paid tribute to a grandmother who immigrated to Britain from Guyana as a teenager seeking a new life.

‚ÄúI must say I‚Äôm up here as a granddaughter of an immigrant,‚Äù she said, evoking cheers from the star-studded audience. ‚ÄúI am a product of bravery and I think those people deserve to be celebrated. We‚Äôre nothing without each other.‚Äù

Lamar, the chart-topping hip-hop sensation who led the field of Grammy contenders going into Sunday‚Äôs show with nine nominations, came away with five awards, including best rap album for his latest studio set ‚ÄúGNX‚Äù and a shared award for record of the year for ‚Äúluther,‚Äù his wistful duet with R&B singer-songwriter SZA.

The award for song of the year, honoring composers, went to Billie Eilish and her brother Finneas O‚ÄôConnell, for her hit single ‚ÄúWildflower.‚Äù

‚ÄúGolden,‚Äù the smash hit from the Netflix NFLX.O animated movie ‚ÄúKPop Demon Hunters,‚Äù made history during the non-televised portion of the awards when it was named best song written for visual media, marking the first time the KPop music genre has ever earned Grammy glory.

The song was performed in the film by a fictional band called HUNTR/X, voiced by real-life vocalists EJAE, Audrey Nuna and Rein Ami.

Lady Gaga won Grammys for best pop vocal album with ‚ÄúMayhem,‚Äù and best dance-pop recording for ‚ÄúAbracadabra.‚Äù

Trevor Noah returned to host the festivities for a sixth time, which he had said would be his last Grammys gig. The show aired live on the CBS network from the Crypto.com Arena in downtown Los Angeles.

Legendary filmmaker Steven Spielberg, 79, achieved EGOT status ‚Äî one of the rarest honors in the entertainment industry ‚Äî after winning his first Grammy award for best music film for ‚ÄúMusic by John Williams,‚Äù which he produced. EGOT stands for Emmy, Grammy, Oscar and Tony.

Grammy winners are chosen by the roughly 15,000 voting members of the Recording Academy ‚Äî industry peers including artists, songwriters, producers and engineers ‚Äî whose ranks have been revamped over the past seven years to increase diversity. About 1,000 Latin Grammys voters became eligible to vote this year, and 73% of members have joined since 2019.
news.summary:
LOS ANGELES, (Reuters) – Bad Bunny, the Latino rap star whose forthcoming Super Bowl gig has ignited a culture wars controversy, won the top Grammy prize yesterday, a first for a Spanish-language album, with “Deb√≠ Tirar M√°s Fotos,” a celebration of his Puerto Rican roots.


The article Bad Bunny wins top Grammy prize in a first for a Spanish-language album appeared first on Stabroek News.
news.author: Staff Editor

news.title: How Taylor Rehmet upset a MAGA candidate to flip a North Texas Senate district
news.text:
In September 2024, Texas Rep. Ram√≥n Romero was at a fundraiser in Fort Worth for Kamala Harris when he met a young labor leader named Taylor Rehmet.

The Air Force veteran and union machinist told Romero he was mulling a run for public office. A lot of people think about running, Romero recounted telling him, but he offered to help should Rehmet actually file. 

The two stayed in touch, and Rehmet decided last summer to run in a special election for a ruby red Texas Senate district in Tarrant County that no Democrat had represented in nearly half a century and that President Donald Trump won by more than 17 points in 2024. When Romero mobilized to help Rehmet court Latino voters ‚Äî many of them from the same Fort Worth neighborhoods he represents in the House ‚Äî he saw a serious first-time candidate meeting power brokers, talking to voters on front porches and running a long-shot bid like he could win it. 

On Saturday, Rehmet did win it, in part thanks to a spike in support from the Latino vote. 

He defeated conservative activist Leigh Wambsganss ‚Äî whose campaign far outspent Rehmet ‚Äî by a decisive 14-point margin in a stunner that reverberated from Texas to Mar-a-Lago, refreshing Democrats‚Äô dreams of a blue Texas and rattling Republicans as they brace for more aftershocks in November. 

Rehmet‚Äôs upset victory, according to interviews Sunday with half a dozen people who supported or worked on his campaign, is explained by a variety of factors, including the combination of Latino and suburban backlash to once-fringe conservative policies that have taken root in Tarrant County and Washington; a MAGA opponent who drove some of those policies and embraced them on the campaign trail; and a message from Rehmet, centered on his union background, that won over working-class voters, independents and even some moderate Republicans. 

Instrumental to Rehmet‚Äôs victory was the backing he received from Hispanics, who account for slightly more than one in five eligible voters in the district. One analyst found that Rehmet outperformed Harris, the 2024 Democratic presidential nominee, by more than 50 points in some of the largely Hispanic areas of Fort Worth. The remarkable shifts occurred as those voters witnessed immigration agents in recent weeks kill two Americans while trying to carry out the president‚Äôs promised mass deportations. And those same voters, some observers noted, believed Trump would help their financial standing more than what he has delivered in his first year in office. 

Up against Rehmet was a ferocious campaign fueled by some of the GOP‚Äôs biggest heavyweights ‚Äî Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and Trump among them. They backed Wambsganss, who‚Äôs set to get a rematch against Rehmet in November for a four-year term, as Rehmet‚Äôs victory was only to complete the remaining 11 months in a term Republican Kelly Hancock left to become Texas‚Äô acting comptroller.

‚ÄúHe is a hard worker. People think that you can just win elections. You‚Äôre gonna have to really work it, and he did,‚Äù Romero, who block-walked for Rehmet, said in an interview Sunday. ‚ÄúI had more Republicans ‚Äî people calling me saying, ‚ÄòI voted for Rehmet.‚Äô ‚ÄòI voted for Rehmet.‚Äô ‚ÄòHey, I just want you to know ‚Äî I voted for Rehmet.‚Äô‚Äù

To be sure, the election was unique. It was held on a Saturday in January, with no other candidates on the ballot, following a cold snap that affected campaigning and early voting. The singularity limits what can be gleaned from Rehmet‚Äôs stunning upset. But as the blame game among Republicans grew louder on Sunday, it also became clear that the 32-point swing for Democrats could not be simply dismissed as irrelevant. 

Still, some Democrats counseled restraint in interpreting the results. 

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that Democrats should think that just because Taylor won last night, that it‚Äôs New York City time. It‚Äôs not New York City time. It‚Äôs not Vermont time. It‚Äôs not LA time,‚Äù said U.S. Rep. Marc Veasey, a Fort Worth Democrat, noting that Texas is far from becoming one of the country‚Äôs liberal bastions. ‚ÄúIf you are a candidate running in a tough race in a place like Texas, it does not mean that you can start California dreaming.‚Äù

By numerous indications, the election should have been a sleepy one. Aside from Trump‚Äôs margin in 2024, the district has been reliably red: Per one analysis, Republicans have carried it by an average of nearly 19 points in 44 state and federal contests since 2018. 

The first indication that the race would be a live one arrived in November, when Rehmet finished three points shy of winning the seat outright. 

In both rounds, but especially in the runoff, Texas GOP leaders went to bat for Wambsganss, tapping into their own funds, block-walking the district and ringing alarms about the race, saying they needed to keep the seat red and away from a radical Democrat. 

In all, Wambsganss‚Äô campaign reported raising $2.6 million, almost two-thirds ‚Äî $1.6 million ‚Äî of which came from three of the most powerful and loaded groups in Texas GOP politics. Texans United for a Conservative Majority, started by right-wing West Texas oil billionaires Tim Dunn and Farris Wilks, gave her campaign nearly $603,000 ‚Äî more than Rehmet‚Äôs entire campaign haul of some $570,000.

The Texas Senate Leadership Fund, a PAC started by Patrick, who oversees the state Senate, added $463,250. And the influential tort reform group Texans For Lawsuit Reform PAC added $550,000.

Rehmet‚Äôs campaign knew it simply could not raise the same amount of money, his campaign strategist Jake Davis said in an interview Sunday. 

But the camp was also not interested in a strategy that involved matching Wambsganss dollar for dollar, Davis said. Knowing they would be outgunned on the advertising airwaves, Davis instead sought out to assemble a staff of Texans from across the state, based them in Tarrant County and identified a north star of knocking on 40,000 doors. 

Every week, they worked backward from that target ‚Äî spending time with people in their living rooms, kitchens and driveways. The staff received training on active listening, Davis said. If a voter had a question the volunteer did not have an answer for, Rehmet‚Äôs team would run it down ‚Äî sometimes calling the candidate himself in front of the voter. 

‚ÄúWe had to stay relentlessly disciplined,‚Äù Davis said. ‚ÄúEvery single dollar, every hour, every volunteer shift, had to have a purpose. There were so many un-sexy decisions that we had to make.‚Äù

Of course, the campaign received help, like from Romero ‚Äî as well as from Beto O‚ÄôRourke, the Democratic darling who shattered fundraising goals and expectations in 2018 when he almost unseated U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz. 

O‚ÄôRourke‚Äôs political group, Powered by People, helped register people to vote in the district, stayed in touch with them to encourage them to vote and called and texted 30,000 voters eligible to vote by mail. In an interview Sunday, the former El Paso congressman credited Rehmet‚Äôs campaign for the victory ‚Äî and struck an optimistic tone for Democrats in November. 

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think any Republican is safe right now,‚Äù O‚ÄôRourke said. ‚ÄúI think the people of Texas have absolutely had it and are looking for change.‚Äù

Bo French, until recently the Tarrant County GOP chair, blamed poor turnout among Republican voters.

‚ÄúI see a lot of Republicans blaming everyone from the Governor to the county party,‚Äù French wrote on social media. ‚ÄúRepublicans need to wake up. When you stay home during local elections and special elections, Democrats win. You can‚Äôt blame others for your failure to vote.‚Äù

Some party superiors see a serious threat. In an early Sunday social media post, Patrick vowed to keep fighting and take the seat back in November.

‚ÄúLow turnout special elections are always unpredictable,‚Äù Patrick wrote. ‚ÄúThe results from SD 9 are a wake-up call for Republicans across Texas. Our voters cannot take anything for granted.‚Äù

Trump, for his part, distanced himself from the loss, spinning heads in the process after he had posted three different get-out-the-vote messages in the 48 hours leading up to the election. 

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not involved in that,‚Äù Trump told reporters at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a local Texas race.‚Äù

As political observers tried to make sense of the upset, a range of theories emerged to explain what still remained inexplicable to many as the dust settled: It was a referendum on Trump, it was a response to socially conservative policies, it was a response to the hard-right turn of local GOP leaders, it was a poorly run GOP campaign, and onward.

John Huffman, the Republican former Southlake mayor who finished a distant third in the November election, chalked it up to ‚Äúfailed opportunities to unify.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere was no outreach to the 19,000 voters who supported our campaign in November,‚Äù Huffman wrote on social media. ‚ÄúNor did Leigh‚Äôs campaign reach out to me until days before early voting began, leaving no time to unify Republicans or broaden the coalition. When she and I finally did meet, she ended the conversation almost as soon as it started.‚Äù

Wambsganss pushed back on Huffman‚Äôs statement during an interview Monday morning with conservative radio host Mark Davis. She blamed Republicans who did not turn out to vote but said the weather also affected some voters. She also said it was time for the GOP to unite, adding Tarrant County is not as red as it once was.

‚ÄúI think this is a really good wake up for Texas that Texas needed,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúRepublicans have to stop the infighting and move on and do what‚Äôs best [for] keeping Texas conservative and free.‚Äù

On paper, Wambsganss‚Äô conservative bona fides were unmatched by many GOP candidates seeking office in Texas.

She is the chief communications officer for Patriot Mobile, a cellphone company that has helped back the Christian conservative school board candidates who overhauled libraries, curricula and raised hell in board meetings across the state about what children are taught.

She had the backing of party state leaders and the district‚Äôs former state senator.

‚ÄúThey could have built her in their garage,‚Äù veteran Texas Democratic operative Matt Angle said. ‚ÄúTaylor Rehmet is just an absolute reflection of that district. Leigh Wambsganss is an absolute reflection of national MAGA. The voters decided which one they like, and it wasn‚Äôt a close call.‚Äù

Still, political observers reiterated the uniqueness of the election and the challenges of trying to draw conclusions from an election that only drew a sliver of registered voters. 

Jason Villalba, a former Republican state representative who now leads the Texas Hispanic Policy Foundation, predicted Latinos ‚Äî ‚Äúthe most important swing vote in the country,‚Äù he said ‚Äî will continue to vote in surprising ways in coming elections. He cautioned that such voting trends ‚Äúin today‚Äôs climate move at light speed.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you can take what happened last night and say, that‚Äôs gonna hold into November, and these numbers are now static and nothing‚Äôs going to change,‚Äù Villalba said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs early. This was a strong indicator that Hispanics are moving back toward Democrats.‚Äù
news.summary: Observers of the race said Rehmet‚Äôs working-class appeal, along with Latino and suburban backlash to GOP policies, fueled his win in a district Donald Trump carried by 17 points.
news.author: Alejandro Serrano

news.title: A new poll shows Trump’s core base is shrinking
news.text:
President Donald Trump appears to have lost a significant amount of support from a critical sector of his own party since last year. It‚Äôs a bad sign for his maximalist governing strategy ‚Äî and a hopeful bit of news for those organizing a coalition against his autocratic agenda.

According to the Pew Research Center, which surveyed more than 8,000 U.S. adults between Jan. 20 and Jan. 26, Trump‚Äôs approval rating has dropped from 40% in the fall to 37% today, and 50% say that the Trump administration‚Äôs actions have been worse than they expected, versus 21% who say they‚Äôre better than expected. But here‚Äôs where it gets strikingly bad for the president: ‚ÄúOnly about a quarter of Americans today (27%) say they support all or most of Trump‚Äôs policies and plans, down from 35% when he returned to office last year. That change has come entirely among Republicans,‚Äù Pew reported.

That response ‚Äî whether you support all or most of the president‚Äôs plans ‚Äî is a decent proxy for the president‚Äôs core base, the swath of the public that‚Äôs likely to sign off on anything he does. Considering that Trump is showing fascistic ambition with the way he‚Äôs transforming Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, into a rogue paramilitary force, seeking to annex foreign territories and suppressing free speech, that‚Äôs an uncomfortably large swath of the population for a country that prides itself on being the oldest democracy in the world.

Trump‚Äôs approval on immigration has plummeted across many surveys over the past year.

But combined with the roughly 10-percentage-point decline in his overall approval ratings since getting elected, it‚Äôs clear that Trump has markedly less political capital than during the pro-Trump ‚Äúvibe shift‚Äù that took place when Trump narrowly won the popular vote, and an Electoral College landslide, in the 2024 election.

Part of what‚Äôs driving it appears to be Trump‚Äôs failure to address the affordability crisis. In November, a Politico poll, conducted by Public First, found that a majority of Trump voters believed he was partially or entirely responsible for an economy that many of them believe suffers from an unprecedented cost-of-living crisis. A Reuters-Ipsos survey conducted Jan. 12-13 found Trump‚Äôs economic approval rating at 34%, and only 30% approval of his handling of the cost of living.

Another likely factor is the salience of Trump‚Äôs aggressive immigration enforcement agenda, which has resulted in the killing of two U.S. citizens in brutal shootings. Trump‚Äôs approval on immigration has plummeted across many surveys over the past year, and ‚Äúabolish ICE‚Äù has skyrocketed in popularity. Kristen Soltis Anderson, a Republican pollster, wrote in The New York Times on Thursday that her polling showed that Trump‚Äôs immigration rating had flipped from 55% approval to 55% disapproval in the past year. 

‚ÄúOn one side of the ledger, there is a decreasing sense that roundups and deportations by federal agents are focused on true security threats,‚Äù Anderson wrote. ‚ÄúOn the other, there is rising anxiety that the presence of an armed federal force in cities is actively making daily life less safe for people who live there.‚Äù 

Notably, the economy and immigration were widely considered to be Trump‚Äôs winning issues in the 2024 election ‚Äî the key reasons he prevailed over former Vice President Kamala Harris. Now that he‚Äôs lost his footing on those issues, his support within his party is ebbing back toward his most die-hard supporters, the ones who Trump famously boasted would support him even if he shot someone on Fifth Avenue. Given the way the Trump administration has tried to defend ICE acting as a secret police force with their approval, he‚Äôs probably right. But he doesn‚Äôt have anywhere close to the backing of the whole party on everything he wants to do.

Trump‚Äôs de-escalation in Minnesota shows he knows this, and that he‚Äôs wary of burning too much political capital on any specific controversial operation. But he also probably overestimates his ability to recover the kind of support he briefly held around his election. 

The president‚Äôs growing unpopularity is a major opportunity for the pro-democracy coalition on the left to expand and contain Trump‚Äôs power. That could come in the form of persuading disenchanted Republicans to flip toward Democrats during the midterms, or building broader backing for protest movements against Trump‚Äôs assaults on democratic features of the country ‚Äî many of which are surely yet to come.
news.author: Ja‚Äôhan Jones
